lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the three mating systems that predominate among birds are polyandry polygyny and monogamy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: monogamy is seen in approximately 91% of all bird species
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: polygyny constitutes 2% of all birds and polyandry is seen in less than 1%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: monogamous species of males and females pair for the breeding season
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some cases the individuals may pair for life
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one reason for the high rate of monogamy among birds is the fact that male birds are just as adept at parental care as females
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in most groups of animals male parental care is rare but in birds it is quite common in fact it is more extensive in birds than in any other vertebrate class
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in birds male care can be seen as important or essential to female fitness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in one form of monogamy such as with obligate monogamy a female cannot rear a litter without the aid of a male"
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the parental behavior most closely associated with monogamy is male incubation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: interestingly male incubation is the most confining male parental behavior
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it takes time and also may require physiological changes that interfere with continued mating
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this extreme loss of mating opportunities leads to a reduction in reproductive success among incubating males
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this information then suggests that sexual selection may be less intense in taxa where males incubate hypothetically because males allocate more effort to parental care and less to mating"
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in other words in bird species in which male incubation is common females tend to select mates on the basis of parental behaviors rather than physical appearance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: birds are an important food source for humans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most commonly eaten species is the domestic chicken and its eggs although geese pheasants turkeys and ducks are also widely eaten
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other birds that have been utilized for food include emus ostriches pigeons grouse quails doves woodcocks songbirds and others including small passerines such as finches
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: birds grown for human consumption are referred to as poultry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at one time swans and flamingos were delicacies of the rich and powerful although these are generally protected now
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: besides meat and eggs birds provide other items useful to humans including feathers for bedding and decoration guano derived phosphorus and nitrogen used in fertilizer and gunpowder and the central ingredient of bird's nest soup
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many species have become extinct through over hunting such as the passenger pigeon and many others have become endangered or extinct through habitat destruction deforestation and intensive agriculture being common causes for declines
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: numerous species have come to depend on human activities for food and are widespread to the point of being pests
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the common pigeon or rock dove columba livia thrives in urban areas around the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in north america introduced house sparrows common starlings and house finches are similarly widespread
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other birds have long been used by humans to perform tasks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example homing pigeons were used to carry messages before the advent of modern instant communications methods many are still kept for sport
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: falcons are still used for hunting while cormorants are employed by fishermen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: chickens and pigeons are popular as experimental subjects and are often used in biology and comparative psychology research
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as birds are very sensitive to toxins the canary was used in coal mines to indicate the presence of poisonous gases allowing miners sufficient time to escape without injury
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: colorful particularly tropical birds e.g parrots and mynahs are often kept as pets although this practice has led to the illegal trafficking of some endangered species cites an international agreement adopted in 1963 has considerably reduced trafficking in the bird species it protects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bird diseases that can be contracted by humans include psittacosis salmonellosis campylobacteriosis newcastle's disease mycobacteriosis avian tuberculosis avian influenza giardiasis and cryptosporidiosis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to worldwatch institute bird populations are declining worldwide with 1200 species facing extinction in the next century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: among the biggest cited reasons are habitat loss predation by nonnative species oil spills and pesticide use hunting and fishing and climate change.-->
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: * bird wikipedia edisi basa inggris 10 agustus 2006 <references >

lines.value: dina statistik teorema rao blackwell ngagambarkeun hiji tehnik nu bisa ngarobah bentuk estimator nu teu jelas jadi hiji estimator nu optimal ku kriteria mean-kasalahan kuadrat atawa kriteria sejen nu ampir sarupa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pronunciation rao rhymes with cow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: salah sahiji teorema rao blackwell nyebutkeun :kuadrat kasalahan mean ti estimator rao blackwell teu leuwih gede tina estimator asli
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina kalimah sejen the more general version of the rao blackwell theorem speaks of the expected loss where the loss function l may be any convex function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for the proof of the more general version jensen's inequality cannot be dispensed with
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the improved estimator is unbiased if and only if the original estimator is unbiased as may be seen at once by using the law of total expectation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the theorem holds regardless of whether biased or unbiased estimators are used
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the theorem seems very weak it says only that the allegedly improved estimator is no worse than the original estimator
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in practice however the improvement is often enormous as an example can show
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: phone calls arrive at a switchboard according to a poisson process at an average rate of &lambda per minute
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this rate is not observable but the numbers of phone calls that arrived during n successive one minute periods are observed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is desired to estimate the probability e −&lambda that the next one minute period passes with no phone calls
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the answer given by rao blackwell may perhaps be unexpected
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a extremely crude estimator of the desired probability is since the average number x 1 + + x n of calls arriving during the first n minutes is n&lambda one might not be surprised if this estimator has a fairly high probability if n is big of being close to so &delta 1 is clearly a very much improved estimator of that last quantity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in case the sufficient statistic is also a complete statistic i.e one which admits no unbiased estimator of zero the rao blackwell process is idempotent i.e using it to improve the already improved estimator does not do so but mere ly returns as its output the same improved estimator
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the improved estimator is both unbiased and complete then the teorema lehmann scheff&eacute implies that it is the unique best unbiased estimator
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in human anatomy the body and its parts are always described using the assumption that the body is in anatomical position i.e standing upright
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: portions of the body which are closer to the head end are superior upper those which are farther away are inferior lower superior corresponds to cranial and inferior to caudal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: objects near the front are anterior those near the rear are posterior these correspond respectively to ventral and dorsal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on the limbs an object closer to the main body is proximal an object farther away is distal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the terms anterior and posterior should not be used when referring to most animals however and are particularly incorrect for quadrupeds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: three basic reference planes are used in zoological anatomy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the sagittal plane divides the body into left and right halves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a coronal plane divides the body into dorsal and ventral halves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a transverse plane divides the body into cranial and caudal halves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometimes the orientation of certain planes need to be distinguished for instance in medical imaging techniques such as ct scans mri scans or pet scans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one imagines a human in anatomical position standing arms hanging down with palms to the front and an x y z coordinate system with the x y plane parallel to the ground the x axis going from left to right the y axis passing from front to back and the z axis going up and down
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: structures near the midline are called medial and those near the sides of animals are called lateral
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: therefore medial structures are closer to the midsagittal plane lateral structures are further from the midsagittal plane
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: structures in the midline of the body are median
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example your cheeks are lateral to your nose and the tip of the nose is in the median line
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: structures that are close to the center of the body are proximal or central while ones far removed are distal or peripheral
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the hands are at the distal end of the arms while the shoulders are at the proximal ends
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these terms can also be used relatively to organs for example the proximal end of the urethra is attached to the bladder
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: structures on or closer to the body's surface are superficial or external and those further inside are profound or deep or internal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when speaking of inner organs visceral means close to or attached to the organ while parietal is more distant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the visceral pleura is attached to the lung and the parietal pleura is attached to the chest wall
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the limbs the terms cranial and caudal are used in the regions proximal to the carpus the wrist in the forelimb and the tarsus the ankle in the hindlimb
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: objects and surfaces closer to or facing towards the head are cranial those facing away or further from the head are caudal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: distal to the carpal joint the term dorsal replaces cranial and palmar replaces caudal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly distal to the tarsal joint the term dorsal replaces cranial and and plantar replaces caudal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the top of a dog's paw is its dorsal surface the underside either the palmar on the forelimb or the plantar on the hindlimb surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the sides of the forearm are named after its bones structures closer to the radius are radial and structures closer to the ulna are ulnar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly in the lower leg structures near the tibia shinbone are tibial and structures near the fibula are fibular or peroneal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: flexion means approximating adjacent parts of the body usually at a joint and extension means separating them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the legs are flexed at the knee joints when sitting down and extended when standing up
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: generally flexion produces an acute angle between adjacent parts with its vertex at the joint and extension produces an obtuse angle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one exception to this rule is in the ankle joint where moving the foot such that the toes move upwards is dorsiflexion and moving the foot such that the toes move downwards is plantar flexion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: adduction means moving a part of the body toward or past its median line or toward the long axis of a limb
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: abduction means moving a part of the body away from its median line or away from the long axis of a limb
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example adducting the thighs brings the legs together and abducting the thighs spreads the legs apart
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly adducting the fingers brings them into contact with one another and abducting the fingers spreads them apart
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rotation means moving a part about its long axis for example in turning the neck
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: supination means rotation of the forearm such that the palm of the hand faces forward or upward and pronation means rotation of the forearm such that the palm of the hand faces backward or downward the forearm with the hand is supinated or pronated at the elbow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similar movements may be accomplished at the ankle where supination results in the foot tipping inward relative to its long axis and pronation results in the foot tipping outward overpronation may contribute to the condition flatfoot
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an anterograde motion is in the normal direction of flow while retrograde means reversed flow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example passage of food from the mouth to the stomach is in an anterograde direction and gastric reflux is in a retrograde direction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nomina anatomica veterinaria
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: metodeu taguchi nyaeta metodeu statistik nu diwangun ku genichi taguchi keur ningkatkeun kualitas produksi pabrik
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: metoda taguchi mangrupa hal nu kontroversi keur statistikawan urang kulon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: prinsip taguchi nu mangaruhan kana statistik nyaeta
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taguchi's reaction to the classical desain percobaan methodology of r a fisher was that it was perfectly adapted in seeking to improve the mean outcome of a process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as fisher's work had been largely motivated by programmes to increase agricultural production this was hardly surprising
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however taguchi realised that in much industrial production there is a need to produce an outcome on target for example to machine a hole to a specified diameter or to manufacture a cell to produce a given voltage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he also realised as had walter a shewhart and others before him that excessive variation lay at the root of poor manufactured quality and that reacting to individual items inside and outside specification was counter productive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he therefore argued that quality engineering should start with an understanding of the cost of poor quality in various situations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in much conventional industrial engineering the cost of poor quality is simply represented by the number of items outside specification multiplied by the cost of rework or scrap
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however taguchi insisted that manufacturers broaden their horizons to consided cost to society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though the short term costs may simply be those of non conformance any item manufactured away from nominal would result in some loss to the customer or the wider community through early wear out difficulties in interfacing with other parts themselves probably wide of nominal or the need to build in safety margins
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these losses are externalities and are usually ignored by manufacturers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the wider economy the coase theorem predicts that they prevent markets from operating efficiently
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taguchi argued that such losses would inevitably find their way back to the originating corperation in an effect similar to the tragedy of the commons and that by working to minimise them manufacturers would enhance brand reputation win markets and generate profits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such losses are of course very small when an item is near to nominal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: donald j wheeler characterised the region within specification limits as where we deny that losses exist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as we diverge from nominal losses grow until the point where losses are too great to deny and the specification limit is drawn
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all these losses are as w edwards deming would describe them unknown and unknowable but taguchi wanted to find a useful way of representing them within statistics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taguchi specified three situations though much of this thinking is endorsed by statisticians and economists in general taguchi extended the argument to insist that industrial experiments seek to maximise an appropriate signal to noise ratio representing the magnitude of the mean of a process compared to its variation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most statisticians believe taguchi's signal to noise ratios to be effective over too narrow a range of applications and they are generally deprecated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taguchi realised that the best opportunity to eliminate variation is during design of a product and its manufacturing process taguchi's rule for manufacturing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: consequently he developed a strategy for quality engineering that can be used in both contexts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the process has three stages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is design at the conceptual level involving creativity and innovation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once the concept is established the nominal values of the various dimensions and design parameters need to be set the detailed design phase of conventional engineering
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1802 philosopher william paley had observed that the inverse square law of gravitation was the only law that resulted in stable orbits if the planets were perturbed in their motion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: paley's understanding that engineering should aim at designs robust against variation led him to use the phenomenon of gravitation as an argument for the existence of god
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: william sealey gosset in his work at the guinness brewery suggested as early as the beginning of the 20th century that the company might breed strains of barley that not only yielded and malted well but whose characteristics were robust against variation in the different soils and climates in which they were grown
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taguchi's radical insight was that the exact choice of values required is underspecified by the performance requirements of the system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in many circumstances this allows the parameters to be chosen so as to minimise the effects on performance arising from variation in manufacture environment and cumulative damage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this approach is often known as robust design
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with a successfully completed parameter design and an understanding of the effect that the various parameters have on performance resources can be focused on reducing and controlling variation in the critical few dimensions see pareto principle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taguchi developed much of his thinking in isolation from the school of r a fisher only coming into direct contact in 1954
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his framework for design of experiments is idioyncratic and often flawed but contains much that is of enormous value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he made a number of innovations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in his later work r a fisher had started to consider the prospect of using design of experiments to understand variation in a wider inductive basis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taguchi sought to understand the influence that parameters had on variation not just on the mean
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he contended as had w edwards deming in his discussion of analytic studies that conventional sampling is inadequate here as there is no way of obtaining a random sample of future conditions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in conventional design of experiments variation between experimental replications is a nuisance that the experimenter would like to eliminate whereas in taguchi's thinking it is a central object of investigation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taguchi's innovation was to replicate each experiment by means of an outer array itself an orthogonal array that seeks deliberately to emulate the sources of variation that a product would encounter in reality
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is an example of judgement sampling
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though statisticians following in the shewhart deming tradition have embraced outer arrays many academics are still sceptical
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an alternative approach proposed by ellis r ott is to use a chunk variable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many of the orthogonal arrays that taguchi has advocated are saturated allowing no scope for estimation of interactions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is a continuing topic of controversy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: taguchi ngawanohkeun sababaraha metoda keur analisa hasil percobaan kaasup ngalarpkeun novel analisa varian sarta analisa menit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: saeutik tina pagaweanana geus di validasai ku statistikawan urang kulon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: genichi taguchi has made seminal and valuable methodological innovations in statistics and engineering within the shewhart deming tradition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his emphasis on loss to society techniques for investigating variation in experiments and his overall strategy of system parameter and tolerance design have been massively influential in improving manufactured quality worldwide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: much of his work was carried out in isolation from the mainstream of western statistics and while this may have facilitated his creativity much of the technical detail of taguchi methods is flawed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: probabiliti with non zero probability defines another probability
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following three axioms are known as the kolmogorov axioms after andrey kolmogorov who developed them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: : for any set satisfies that is the probability that a or b will happen is the sum of the probabilities that a will happen and that b will happen minus the probability that a and b will happen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this can be extended to the inclusion exclusion principle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: four organs are subject to specialization in the kingdom animalia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gastrointestinal tract is also a prominent part of the immune system coico et al 2003

lines.value: the low ph ranging from 1 to 4 of the stomach is fatal for many microorganisms that enter it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly mucus containing iga antibodies neutralize many of these microorganisms

lines.value: other factors in the gi tract help with immune function as well including enzyme in the saliva and bile

lines.value: health enhancing intestinal bacteria serve to prevent the overgrowth of potentially harmful bacteria in the gut

lines.value: no single time or person can be identified with the invention of the bicycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its earliest known forebears were called velocipedes and included many types of human powered vehicles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of these the scooter like dandy horse of the french comte de sivrac dating to 1790 was long cited as the earliest bicycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most bicycle historians now believe that these hobby horses with no steering mechanism probably never existed but were made up by louis baudry de saunier a 19th-century french bicycle historian
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most likely originator of the bicycle is german karl drais then still a baron who invented his 1817 machine to replace starved horses after the tambora catastrophe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he patented his draisine a number of which still exist including one at the paleis het loo museum in apeldoorn the netherlands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these were pushbikes powered by the action of the rider's feet pushing against the ground
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: scottish blacksmith kirkpatrick macmillan was believed to share creative credit with drais for adding a treadle drive mechanism in 1840 that enabled the rider to lift his feet off the ground while driving the rear wheel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however some reports describe the vehicle attributed to macmillan as more of a quadricycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1850s and 1860s frenchman ernest michaux and his pupil pierre lallement took bicycle design in a different direction placing pedals on an enlarged front wheel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: their creation which came to be called the boneshaker featured a heavy steel frame on which they mounted wooden wheels with iron tires
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lallement emigrated to america where he recorded a patent on his bicycle in 1866 in new haven connecticut
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the boneshaker was further refined by james starley in the 1870s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he mounted the seat more squarely over the pedals so that the rider could push more firmly and further enlarged the front wheel to increase the potential for speed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with tires of solid rubber his machine became known as the ordinary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: british cyclists likened the disparity in size of the two wheels to their coinage nicknaming it the penny farthing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the primitive bicycles of this generation were difficult to ride and the high seat and poor weight distribution made for dangerous falls
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the subsequent dwarf ordinary addressed some of these faults by adding gearing reducing the front wheel diameter and setting the seat further back with no loss of speed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: having to both pedal and steer via the front wheel remained a problem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: starley's nephew j k starley j h lawson and shergold solved this problem by introducing the chain and producing rear wheel drive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these models were known as dwarf safeties or safety bicycles for their lower seat height and better weight distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: starley's 1885 rover is usually described as the first recognizably modern bicycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: soon the seat tube was added creating the double triangle diamond frame of the modern bike
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while the starley design was much safer the return to smaller wheels made for a bumpy ride
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the next innovations increased comfort and ushered in the 1890s golden age of bicycles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1888 scotsman john boyd dunlop introduced the pneumatic tire which soon became universal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shortly thereafter the rear freewheel was developed enabling the rider to coast without the pedals spinning out of control
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this refinement led to the 1898 invention of coaster brakes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: derailleur gears and hand operated cable pull brakes were also developed during these years but were only slowly adopted by casual riders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the turn of the century bicycling clubs flourished on both sides of the atlantic and touring and racing were soon the rage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: successful early bicycle manufacturers included englishman frank bowden and german builder ignaz schwinn
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bowden started the raleigh company in nottingham in the 1890s and soon was producing some 30000 bicycles a year
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: schwinn emigrated to the united states where he founded his similarly successful company in chicago in 1895
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: schwinn bicycles soon featured widened tires and spring cushioned padded seats sacrificing some efficiency for increased comfort
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: facilitated by connections between european nations and their overseas colonies european style bicycles were soon available worldwide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the mid 20th century bicycles had become the primary means of transportation for millions of people around the globe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in many western countries the use of bicycles levelled off or declined as motorized transportation became affordable and car centred policies led to an increasingly hostile road environment for bicycles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in north america bicycle sales declined markedly after 1905 to the point where by the 1940s they had largely been relegated to the role of children's toys
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in other parts of the world however such as china india and european countries such as germany denmark and the netherlands the traditional utility bicycle remained a mainstay of transportation its design only gradually changing to incorporate hand operated brakes and internal hub gears allowing up to seven speeds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the netherlands such so called granny bikes have remained popular and are again in production
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: especially in amsterdam they are often colourfully painted and or otherwise decorated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in north america increasing consciousness of physical fitness and environmental preservation spawned a renaissance of bicycling in the late 1960s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bicycle sales in the united states boomed largely in the form of the racing bicycles long used in such events as the hugely popular tour de france
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sales were also helped by a number of technical innovations that were new to the us market including higher performance steel alloys and gearsets with an increasing number of gears
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while 10-speeds were the rage in the 1970s 12-speed designs were introduced in the 1980s and today most bikes feature 18 or more speeds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the 1980s these newer designs had driven the three speed bicycle from the roads
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the late 1980s the mountain bike became particularly popular and in the 1990s something of a major fad
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these task specific designs led many american recreational cyclists to demand a more comfortable and practical product
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: manufacturers responded with the hybrid bicycle which restored many of the features long enjoyed by riders of the time tested european utility bikes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 1968 vienna convention on road traffic considers a bicycle to be a vehicle and a person controlling a bicycle is considered a driver
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the traffic codes of many countries reflect these definitions and demand that a bicycle satisfy certain legal requirements including licencing before it can be used on public roads
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in many jurisdictions it is an offence to use a bicycle that is not in roadworthy condition and which does not have functioning front and rear brakes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some places bicycles must have functioning front and rear lights or lamps
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as some generator or dynamo driven lamps only operate while moving rear reflectors are frequently also mandatory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since a moving bicycle makes very little noise in many countries bicycles must have a warning bell for use when approaching pedestrians equestrians and other bicyclists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nearly all modern upright bicycles feature the diamond frame composed of two triangles the front triangle and the rear triangle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the front triangle consists of the head tube top tube down tube and seat tube
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the head tube contains the headset the interface with the fork
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the top tube connects the head tube to the seat tube at the top and the down tube connects the head tube to the bottom bracket
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the rear triangle consists of the seat tube and paired chain stays and seat stays
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the chain stays run parallel to the chain connecting the bottom bracket to the rear dropouts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the seat stays connect the top of the seat tube often at or near the same point as the top tube to the rear dropouts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: historically women's bicycle frames had a top tube that connected in the middle of the seat tube instead of the top resulting in a lower standover height
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this allowed the rider to dismount while wearing a skirt or dress
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although some women's bicycles continue to use this frame style there is also a hybrid form the mixte or step through frame which also allows easier mounting and dismounting for both male and female riders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: historically materials used in bicycles have followed a similar pattern as in aircraft the goal being strength and low weight
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the late 1930s alloy steels have been used for frame and fork tubes in higher quality machines
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: celluloid found application in mudguards and aluminium alloys are increasingly used in components such as handlebars seat stems also known as seatposts and brake levers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1980s aluminium alloy frames became popular and their affordability now makes them common
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more expensive carbon fibre and titanium frames are now also available as well as advanced steel alloys
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the drivetrain begins with pedals which rotate the crankset which fit into the bottom bracket
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: attached to the crank is the chainring which drives the chain which in turn rotates the rear wheel via the rear sprockets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: between the chain and rear wheel may be interspersed various gearing systems described below which vary the number of rear wheel revolutions produced by each turn of the pedals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since cyclists legs produce a limited amount of power most efficiently over a narrow range of cadences a variable gear ratio is needed to maintain an optimum pedaling speed while covering varied terrain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gear systems are hand operated via cables or rarely hydraulics and are of two types
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: internal hub gearing still predominates in some regions particularly on utility bikes whereas in other regions such as the usa external derailleur systems predominate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: road bicycles have close set multi step gearing which allows very fine control of cadence while utility cycles offer fewer more widely spaced speeds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mountain bikes and most entry level road racing bikes may offer an extremely low gear to facilitate climbing slowly on steep hills
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fixed gear track racing bikes have transmission efficiencies of over 99% nearly all the energy put in at the pedals ends up at the wheel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while generally variable ratio gear mechanisms are essential for human efficiency they do reduce mechanical efficiency
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the efficiency varies considerably with the gear ratio being used
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in a typical hub gear mechanism the mechanical efficiency will be between 82% and 92% depending on the ratio selected
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: which ratios are best and worst depends on the specific model of hub gear
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: derailleur type mechanisms fare better with a typical mid range product of the sort used by serious amateurs achieving between 88% and 99% efficiency at 100w
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in derailleur mechanisms the highest efficiency is achieved by the larger cogs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: efficiency generally decreases with smaller cog sizes because the chain must bend more sharply as it rolls on and off the cog and it also forms a sharp angle at the chain tensioner 9
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: derailleur efficiency is also compromised with cross chaining or running large ring to large cog or small ring to small cog
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this also results in increased wear because of the lateral deflection of the chain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: retro direct drivetrains used on some early 20th century bicycles have been resurrected by bicycle hobbyists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the handlebars rotate the fork and the front wheel via the stem which articulates with the headset
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: three styles of handlebar are common
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: touring handlebars the norm in europe and elsewhere until the 1970s curve gently back toward the rider offering a natural grip and comfortable upright position
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: racing handlebars are dropped offering the cyclist either an aerodynamic hunched position or a more upright posture in which the hands grip the brake lever mounts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mountain bikes feature a crosswise handlebar which helps prevent the rider from pitching over the front in case of sudden deceleration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: variations on these styles exist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bullhorn style handlebars are often seen on modern time trial bicycles equipped with two forward facing extensions allowing a rider to rest his entire forearm on the bar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are usually used in conjunction with the aero bar a pair of forward facing extensions spaced close together to promote better aerodynamics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the bullhhorn was banned from ordinary road racing because it is difficult for the rider to control in bike traffic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: seats or saddles also vary with rider preference from the cushioned ones favoured by short distance riders to narrower seats which allow more free leg swings
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: comfort depends on riding position
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with comfort bikes and hybrids the cyclist sits high over the seat their weight directed down onto the saddle such that a wider and more cushioned saddle is preferable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for racing bikes where the rider is bent over weight is more evenly distributed between the handlebars and saddle and the hips are flexed and a narrower and harder saddle is more efficient
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recumbent bicycles have more chair like seats and so are much more comfortable to ride although generally slower up hills due to this positioning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the reclined low seating position does provide increased aerodynamics over standard seating
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bicycle brakes are either rim brakes in which friction pads are compressed against the wheel rims internal hub brakes in which the friction pads are contained within the wheel hubs or disc brakes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a rear hub brake may be either hand operated or pedal actuated as in the back pedal coaster brakes which were the rule in north america until the 1960s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hub drum brakes do not cope well with extended braking so rim brakes are favoured in hilly terrain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with hand operated brakes force is applied to brake handles mounted on the handle bars and then transmitted via bowden cables to the friction pads
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the late 1990s disc brakes appeared on some off road bicycles tandems and recumbent bicycles but are considered impractical on road bicycles which rarely encounter conditions where the advantages of discs are significant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the advantages of discs make them well suited to steep extended downhills through wet and muddy off road terrain which falls under the category of downhill and freeride bicycle riding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the use of tires as large as 3.0 inches in width also makes disc brakes a necessity as rim brakes simply cannot straddle a tire that wide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: two main disc brake systems exist hydraulic and mechanical cable-actuated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mechanical disc brakes have less modulation than hydraulic disc brake systems and since the cable is usually open to the outside mechanical disc brakes tend to pick up small bits of dirt and grit in the cable lines when ridden in harsh terrain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hydraulic disc brake systems generally keep contaminants out better
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however since hydraulic disc brakes usually require relatively specialized tools to bleed the brake systems repairs on the trail are difficult to perform whereas mechanical disc brakes rarely fail
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also the hydraulic fluid may boil on steep continuous downhills
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is due to the brake losing its ability to transmit force through incompressible fluids since some of it has become a gas which is compressible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for these reasons one must weigh the advantages and disadvantages of using a hydraulic system versus a mechanical system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: utility bicycles have many standard features which enhance their usefulness and comfort that would be considered accessories on sports bicycles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: chainguards and mudguards or fenders protect clothes and moving parts from oil and spray
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: kick stands help with parking
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: front mounted wicker or steel baskets for carrying goods are often used
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rear racks or carriers can be used to carry items such as school satchels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: parents sometimes add rear mounted child seats and or an auxiliary saddle fitted to the crossbar to transport children
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other accessories include lights pump lock and additional pedal or wheel mounted reflectors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: technical accessories include solid state speedometers and odometers for measuring distance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: toe clips help to keep the foot planted firmly on the pedals and enable the cyclist to pull as well as push the pedals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in most countries where cycling is common bicycle helmet use is negligible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in north america a significant minority possibly up to 25% of bicyclists wear helmets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while no us federal law requires helmets many states require children to wear them and some municipalities require them for all riders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in australia and new zealand and parts of canada helmets are required by law
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: outside the west use of helmets by utility cyclists is practically unknown
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: no correlation between decreased injury rates and helmet use has been demonstrated in whole populations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many cyclists carry tool kits containing at least a tire patch kit tire levers and spanners
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a single tool once sufficed for most repairs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more specialised parts now require more complex tools including proprietary tools specific for a given manufacturer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some bicycle parts particularly hub based gearing systems are complex and many prefer to leave maintenance and repairs to professionals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: others maintain their own bicycles enhancing their enjoyment of the hobby of cycling
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in both biological and mechanical terms the bicycle is extraordinarily efficient
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in terms of the amount of energy a person must expend to travel a given distance investigators have calculated it to be the most efficient self powered means of transportation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 1 from a mechanical viewpoint up to 99% of the energy delivered by the rider into the pedals is transmitted to the wheels although the use of gearing mechanisms may reduce this by 10-15% 2 9
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in terms of the ratio of cargo weight a bicycle can carry to total weight it is also a most efficient means of cargo transportation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a human being travelling on a bicycle at low to medium speeds of around 10-15 mph 16-24 km h using only the energy required to walk is the most energy efficient means of transport generally available
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: air drag which increases with the square of speed requires increasingly higher power outputs relative to speed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a bicycle in which the rider lies in a prone position and which may be covered in an aerodynamic fairing to achieve very low air drag is referred to as a recumbent bicycle or human powered vehicle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on firm flat ground a 70 kg man requires about 100 watts to walk at 5 km h
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that same man on a bicycle on the same ground with the same power output can average 25 km h so energy expenditure in terms of kcal/kg/km is roughly one fifth as much
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: generally used figures are the average in shape man can produce about 3 watts kg for more than an hour e.g around 200 watts for a 70 kg rider with top amateurs producing 5 watts kg and elite athletes achieving 6 watts kg for similar lengths of time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: elite track sprinters are able to attain an instantaneous maximum output of around 2000 watts or in excess of 25 watts kg elite road cyclists may produce 1600 to 1700 watts as an instantaneous maximum in their burst to the finish line at the end of a five hour long road race
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even at moderate speeds most cycling energy is spent in overcoming aerodynamic drag which increases with the square of speed therefore power needs increase approximately with the cube of speed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typical speeds for bicycles are 16 to 32 km h 10 to 20 mph
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on a fast racing bicycle a reasonably fit rider can ride at 50 km h 30 mph on flat ground for short periods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the highest speed ever officially attained on the flat without using motor pacing and wind blocks is by canadian sam whittingham who in 2002 set a 130.36 km h 81.00 mph record on his highly aerodynamic recumbent bicycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this stands as the official record for all human powered vehicles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there has been major corporate competition to lower the weight of racing bikes through the use of advanced materials and components
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: additionally advanced wheels are available with low friction bearings and other features to lower road resistance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in measured tests these components have almost no effect on cycling performance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for instance lowering a bike's weight by 1 kg a major effort considering they may weigh less than 15 kg to start with will have the same effect over a 40 km time trial as removing a protrusion into the air the size of a pencil
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for this reason more recent designs have concentrated on lowering wind resistance using aerodynamically shaped tubing flat spokes on the wheels and handlebars that allow the rider to bend over into the wind
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these changes can impact performance dramatically cutting minutes off a time trial
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a rider stays upright on a bicycle by steering the bicycle so that the point where the wheels touch the ground stays underneath the center of gravity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once underway this effort is largely replaced by physical forces generated by the rotation of the wheels which produce a remarkable self steering effect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 3 the angular momentum of the wheels and the torque applied to them by the ground generates a phenomenon called precession by which the wheel turns or trails toward whichever side the bicycle tilts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: like the rider's steering adjustments this motion automatically returns the contact point of the wheel directly under the center of gravity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these forces perhaps aided at very high speeds by the gyroscopic effect of the spinning wheels 4 are sufficiently strong that a riderless bicycle going down a slope will stay upright by itself
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: conversely a bicycle whose steering fork is locked in a perfectly straight ahead position is virtually impossible to balance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that gyroscopic effects are unimportant at normal cycling speeds was shown by physicist and researcher into bicycle stability david e h jones whose series of urbs unrideable bikes with various modifications to the front end included a bike which cancelled the gyroscopic effect of the front wheel by dint of attaching a second wheel to his front forks alongside the regular wheel whose lower edge was about an inch 25 mm above the ground
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by gearing this wheel to the regular front wheel so that it spun in the opposite direction at equal speed the net angular momentum of both wheels together was close to zero
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: jones found he could ride this bike with no difficulty but did discover that without a rider the non gyroscopic bike fell over much faster than a regular bike
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: stability is also influenced by a geometric factor called trail
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is the distance between the point of contact the front wheel makes with the ground and the place the steering axis makes contact with the ground
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the greater the amount of trail the greater the reaction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one can see the effect that trail has by simply holding a bicycle by the seat and leaning it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the movement due to trail and the weight of the bicycle will turn the front wheel in the direction of the turn
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: negative trail rolling a bicycle backwards results in immediate steering problems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: zero trail as in a unicycle requires constant rider adjustment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: positive trail found on typical bicycles creates positive stability by steering the contact patch back under the cg of the bicycle and rider
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at higher speeds bicycles can also experience speed wobbles or shimmies where the front wheel spontaneously oscillates to the left and right
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while the wobbles can be easily remedied by slowing down adjusting position or relaxing one's grip on the handlebars speed wobbles can be fatal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this shimmy is often seen in shopping cart front wheels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some otherwise minor irregularity accelerates the wheel to one side
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the restoring force is applied in phase with the progress of the irregularity and the wheel turns to the other side where the process is repeated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if there is insufficient damping in the steering the oscillation will increase until system failure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: speed changes making the bicycle motorcycle stiffer or lighter or increasing the stiffness of the steering of which the rider is the main component can change the oscillation frequency though only speed change is applicable in the situation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for more information on the technical aspects of bicycles see also *list of bicycle parts and
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bicycle manufacturing proved to be a training ground for other industries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: building modern bicycle frames led to the development of advanced metalworking techniques both for the frames themselves and for special components such as ball bearings washers and sprockets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these techniques later enabled skilled metalworkers and mechanics to develop the components used in early automobiles and aircraft
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: j k starley's company became the rover cycle company ltd in the late 1890s and then the rover auto maker
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the morris motor company and skoda also began in the bicycle business as did henry ford and the wright brothers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some bicycle clubs and national associations became prominent advocates for improvements to roads and highways
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the united states the league of american wheelmen was a prominent advocate for the improvement of roads in the last part of the 19th century founding and leading the national good roads movement in the us.the evolution of the bicycle had less tangible effects as well extending early to areas as diverse as fashion and politics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1890s the cycling craze led to a new set of fashions including bloomers which helped liberate women from corsets and other restrictive clothing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a british perfumer marketed cycling bouquet which came in a tiny vial designed to fit into a lady cyclist's purse
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the diamond frame safety bicycle gave women unprecedented mobility contributing to their emancipation in western nations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sociologists suggest that bicycles enlarged the gene pool for rural workers by enabling them to easily reach the next town and increase their courting radius
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in cities bicycles helped reduce crowding in inner city tenements by allowing workers to commute from single family dwellings in the suburbs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they also reduced dependence on horses and allowed people to travel into the country since bicycles were three times as energy efficient as walking and three to four times as fast
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in north america the political organization of bicycle enthusiasts in such groups as the league of american wheelmen led to further changes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: both their model for political organization and the paved roads for which they argued facilitated the growth of the bicycle's rival the automobile
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in recent years us and european bicycle makers have moved much of their production to asia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some sixty percent of the world's bicycles are now being made in china
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite this shift in production as nations such as china and india become more wealthy their own use of bicycles has declined
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of the major reasons for the proliferation of chinese made bicycles in foreign markets is the increasing affordability of cars and motorcycles for its own citizens 5
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the postal services of many countries have long relied on bicycles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the royal mail first started using bicycles in 1880
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bicycle delivery fleets include 37000 in the uk 25700 in germany and 10500 in hungary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: police officers adopted the bicycle as well initially using their own
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however they eventually became a standard issue particularly for police in rural areas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the kent police purchased 20 bicycles in 1896 and by 1904 there were 129 police bicycle patrols operating
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some countries retained the police bicycle while others dispensed with them for a time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bicycle patrols are now enjoying a resurgence in many cities as the mobility of car borne officers is becoming increasingly limited by traffic congestion and pedestrianisation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they also have the advantages that the officers are inherently more open to the public and the transport is quieter to permit a more stealthy approach toward suspects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the pursuit of suspects can also be assisted by a bicycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bicycles have enjoyed substantial use as general delivery vehicles in many cities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the uk this use persisted for some purposes with generations of teenagers getting their first jobs delivering newspapers by bicycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in india many of mumbai's dabbawalas use bicycles to deliver hot lunches to the city's workers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in bogota colombia the city's largest bakery recently replaced most of its delivery trucks with bicycles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even the car industry uses bicycles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the huge mercedes benz factory in sindelfingen germany workers use bicycles colour coded by department to move around the factory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bicycles are used for recreation at all ages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bicycle touring involves touring and exploration or sightseeing with the use of a bicycle for leisure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a brevet or randonnee is an organized long distance ride
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one major aspect of dutch popular culture is enjoying relaxed cycling in the countryside of the netherlands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the land is very flat and full of special public bicycle trails where cyclist aren't bothered by cars and other traffic which makes it ideal for cycling recreation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many dutch people subscribe every year to an event called fietsvierdaagse - four days of organised cycling through the local environment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: paris brest paris pbp which began in 1891 is the oldest bicycling event still run on a regular basis on the open road covers over 1200 km and imposes a 90-hour time limit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the bicycle is not suited for combat but it has been used as a method of transporting soldiers and supplies to combat zones
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bicycles were used in the second boer war where both sides used them for scouting
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in world war i france and germany used bicycles to move troops
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in its 1937 invasion of china japan employed some 50000 bicycle troops and similar forces were instrumental in japan's march through malaya in world war ii
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: germany used bicycles again in world war ii while the british employed airborne cycle commandos with folding bikes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the vietnam war communist forces used bicycles extensively as cargo carriers along the ho chi minh trail
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are reports of mountain bicycles being used in scouting by us special forces in the us invasion of afghanistan and in subsequent battles against the taliban
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the only country to recently maintain a regiment of bicycle troops was switzerland who disbanded the last unit in 2003
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shortly after the introduction of bicycles competitions developed independently in many parts of the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early races involving boneshaker style bicycles were predictably fraught with injuries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: large races became popular during the 1890's golden age of cycling with events across europe and in the us and japan as well
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at one point almost every major city in the us had a velodrome or two for track racing events
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however since the middle of the 20th century cycling has become a minority sport in the us whilst in continental europe it continues to be a major sport particulrly in france belgium and italy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most famous of all bicycle races is the tour de france
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this began in 1903 and continues to capture the attention of the sporting world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as the bicycle evolved its various forms different racing formats developed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: road races may involve both team and individual competition and are contested in various ways
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they range from the one day road race criterium and time trial to multi stage events like the tour de france and its sister events which make up cycling's grand tours
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recumbent bicycles were banned from bike races in 1934 after marcel berthet set a new hour record in his velodyne streamliner 49.992 km on nov 18 1933
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: track bicycles are used for track racing in velodromes while cyclo cross races are held on rugged outdoor terrain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the past decade mountain bike racing has also reached international popularity and is even an olympic sport
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the governing body of international cycle sport the union cycliste international decided in the late 1990s to create additional rules restricting the design of racing bicycles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these rules met with considerable controversy and to some extent arrested the development of the racing bicycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: their stated motive was so that developing countries could compete in international competitions without requiring large equipment budgets and to refocus attention on the athlete rather than the bicyle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: monocoque frames such as used by chris boardman to win the gold medal in 1992 olympic individual pursuit event in barcelona were no longer permitted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cyclists and motorists make different demands on road design which may lead to conflicts both in politics and on the streets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some jurisdictions give priority to motorised traffic for example setting up extensive one way street systems free right turns high capacity roundabouts and slip roads
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other cities may apply active traffic restraint measures to limit the impact of motorised transport
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the former cases cycling has tended to decline while in the latter it has tended to be maintained
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: occasionally extreme measures against cycling may occur
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in shanghai a city where bicycles were once the dominant mode of transportation bicycle travel on city roads was actually banned temporarily in december 2003
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in areas in which cycling is popular and encouraged cycle parking facilities using bicycle racks lockable mini garages and patrolled cycle parks are used to reduce theft
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: local governments also promote cycling by permitting the carriage of bicycles on public transport or by providing external attachment devices on public transport vehicles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: conversely an absence of secure cycle parking is a recurring complaint by cyclists from cities with low modal share of cycling
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: extensive bicycle path systems may be found in some cities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such dedicated paths often have to be shared with inline skaters scooters skateboarders and pedestrians
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: segregating bicycle and automobile traffic in cities has met with mixed success both in terms of safety and bicycle promotion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at some point the two streams of traffic inevitably intersect often in a haphazard and congested fashion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: studies have demonstrated that due to the high incidence of accidents at these sites such segregated schemes can actually increase the number of car bike collisions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cyclists form associations both for specific interests trails development road maintenance urban design racing clubs touring clubs etc and for more global goals energy conservation pollution reduction promotion of fitness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: two broad themes run in bicycle activism one more overtly political with roots in the environmental movement the other drawing on the traditions of the established bicycle lobby
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such groups promote the bicycle as an alternative mode of transport and emphasize the potential for energy and resource conservation and health benefits gained from cycling versus automobile use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: activists in both camps also argue for improved local and inter city rail services and other methods of mass transportation and also for greater provision for cycle carriage on such services
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many cities also have community bicycle programs that promote cycling especially as a means of inner city transport
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: controversially some bicycle activists including some traffic management advisors seek the construction of segregated cycle facilities for journeys of all lengths
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other activists especially those from the more established tradition view the safety practicality and intent of many segregated cycle facilities with suspicion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they favour a more holistic approach based on the 4 e's education of everyone involved encouragement to apply the education enforcement to protect the rights of others and engineering to facilitate travel while respecting every person's equal right to do so
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some cases this opposition has a more ideological basis some members of the vehicular cycling movement oppose segregated public facilities such as on street bike lanes on principle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some groups offer training courses to help cyclists integrate themselves with other traffic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is part of the ongoing cycle path debate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a recent focus especially for european bicycle activists has been opposition to compulsory bicycle helmet legislation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they cite evidence suggesting that compulsory helmet laws and helmet promotion have been associated with significant reductions in bicycle use and with increases in the risk of death or injury to individual cyclists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a consequence activists from both sides have put aside their differences in order to fight the helmet lobby
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: critical mass is a worldwide activist movement of mass bicycle protest rides
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it incorporates the themes of increasing the road and mind share given to bicycle transport and has drawn support from environmentally minded campaigners and other schools of political thought
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to participants in critical mass we aren't blocking traffic we are traffic however their particular forms of protest has drawn criticism from the broader streams of activism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are many different types of bicycle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a number of formal and industry standards exist for bicycle components to help make spare parts exchangeable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some lizard species called glass snakes or glass lizards have no functional legs though there are some vestigial skeletal leg structures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are distinguished from true snakes by the presence of eyelids and ears
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the tail of glass lizards like many other lizards will break off as a defense mechanism unlike snakes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many lizards can change color in response to their environments or in times of stress
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most familiar example is the chameleon but more subtle color changes occur in other lizard species as well most notably the anole also known as the house chameleon or chamele
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lizards typically feed on insects or rodents
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a few species are omnivorous or herbivorous a familiar example of the latter is the iguana which is unable to properly digest animal protein
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: until very recently it was thought that only two lizard species were venomous the mexican beaded lizard and the closely related gila monster both of which live in northern mexico and the southwest united states
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however recent research at the university of melbourne australia and pennsylvania state university has revealed that in fact many lizards in the iguanians and monitor lizard families have venom producing glands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: none of these poses much danger to humans as their poison is introduced slowly by chewing rather than injected as with poisonous snakes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nine toxins previously thought to only occur in snakes have been discovered and a number of previously unseen chemicals as well
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these revelations are prompting calls for a complete overhaul of the classification system for lizard species to form a venom clade
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these papers threaten to radically change our concepts of lizard and snake evolution and particularly of venom evolution says harry greene a herpetologist at cornell university in new york
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most other lizard species are harmless to humans most species native to north america for example are incapable even of drawing blood with their bites
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: only the very largest lizard species pose threat of death the komodo dragon for example has been known to attack and kill humans and their livestock
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gila monster and beaded lizard are venomous however and though not deadly can inflict extremely painful and powerful bites
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the chief impact of lizards on humans is positive they are significant predators of pest species numerous species are prominent in the pet trade some are eaten as food for example iguanas in central america and lizard symbology plays important though rarely predominant roles in some cultures e.g tarrotarro in australian mythology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most lizards lay eggs though a few species are capable of live birth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many are also capable of regeneration of lost limbs or tails
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lizards in the scincomorpha family which include skinks such as the blue tailed skink often have shiny iridescent scales that appear moist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however like all other lizards they are dry skinned and generally prefer to avoid water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all lizards are able to swim if needed however and a few such as the nile monitor are quite comfortable in aquatic environments
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many species of lizard are now sold as pet species
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a few of these include iguanas bearded dragon leopard geckos tegus and monitor lizards to name a few
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in general lizards require more maintenance than other exotic pets particularly snakes and tarantulas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: their faeces are usually more offensive requiring frequent cage cleanings
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suborder lacertilia sauria lizards
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hydrated iron oxide is permeable to air and water meaning that the metal continues to corrode after rust has formed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the iron mass eventually converts entirely to rust and disintegrates
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: corrosion of aluminium is different from steel or iron in that aluminium oxide formed on the surface of aluminium metal forms a protective corrosion resistant coating a process known as passivation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: stainless steel similarly resists rusting by forming a passivation layer of chromium(iii oxide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is also true of magnesium copper and zinc
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: galvanization consists of coating metal with a thin layer of another such metal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically zinc is applied by either hot dip galvanizing or electroplating
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: zinc is traditionally used because it is cheap easy to refine and adheres well to steel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: zinc also provides cathodic protection to metal that itself is unplated but close enough that any water touching bare iron is also in contact with some zinc
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the zinc layer acts as a galvanic anode rusting in preference
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: galvanization often fails at seams holes and joints where the coating is pierced
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more modern coatings add aluminium to the coating as zinc alume aluminium will migrate to cover scratches and thus provide protection for longer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these rely on the aluminium and zinc oxides protecting the once scratched surface rather than oxiding as a sacrificial anode
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are several other methods available to control corrosion and prevent the formation of rust colloquially termed rustproofing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cathodic protection makes the iron a cathode in a battery formed whenever water contacts the iron and also a sacrificial anode made from something with a more negative electrode potential commonly zinc or magnesium
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the electrode itself doesn't react in water but only to provide electrons to prevent the iron rusting
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bluing is a technique that can provide limited resistance to rusting for small steel items such as firearms for it to be successful water displacing oil must always be rubbed onto the blued steel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: corrosion control can be done using a coating to isolate the metal from the environment such as paint
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: covering steel with concrete provides protection to steel by the high ph environment at the steel concrete interface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however if concrete covered steel does corrode the rust formed can cause the concrete to spall and fall apart
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this creates structural problems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to prevent rust corrosion on automobiles they should be kept cleaned and waxed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the underbody should be sprayed to make sure it is loose of any dirt and debris that could trap moisture
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after a car is washed it is best to let it sit in the sun for a few hours to let it air dry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in winter or in salty conditions cars should be washed more regularly as salt sodium chloride can accelerate the rusting process.-->
lines.name: Sundanese
