lines.value: the most widely accepted phonemic theory is that old japanese had eight post consonantal vocalic distinctions i.e vowels as opposed to classical japanese and modern japanese which have only five
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is argued on the basis that phonetic writing in old japanese distinguishes two different forms of some syllables including the vowels <i&gt <e&gt and <o&gt and does so consistently
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in modern romanized transcription the three additional vowels are usually indicated <i&gt <e&gt and <o&gt but this should not be taken to mean that these vowels were necessarily fronted or centralized
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the transcriptions of old japanese words given in the kojiki differ from those found in the nihonshoki and man'yoshu in that they discriminate between the syllables <mo&gt and <mo&gt whereas the latter two do not
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this has been correlated with the historical record of the kojiki being compiled earlier than the nihonshoki and thus probably indicates the preservation of the distinction between and <o&gt after m/
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and its conversion to <o&gt by the late 6th century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the consonant inventory was also smaller in old japanese
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the and sounds did not exist arising later out of old japanese's
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus the honorific portion of the name of the sun goddess amaterasu omikami was written <opomikami&gt
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the heian era the old japanese had been transformed into classical japanese a bilabial fricative often written f word initially and between vowels and it subsequently changed into medially and initially in modern japanese with the exception of <fu&gt ふ which retains the classical pronunciation of
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later was lost everywhere except before
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus the old japanese word kapa river became kafa in classical japanese and now is kawa in modern japanese this same sound process explains why the particle wa is still written は <ha&gt
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly old japanese upper became classical which in turn became modern
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this also explains why the directional particle e is written へ <he&gt which in classical japanese was pronounced
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the modern japanese syllable derives from affrication of before in the old japanese and modern arises by the same process from early modern and old
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: certain modern dialects preserve the distinction between and for instance in the nagoya dialect for mizu water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a similar process of palatalization resulted in modern from classical and old
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however it cannot be ascertained when was palatalized it may have already been an affricate in old japanese
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other characteristic differences of old japanese as compared with its modern counterpart include
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimedes basa yunani apxiunδns ) c
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 287 bc - 212 bc salah saurang ahli matematika fisika rekayasa astronomi sarta filsuf yunani lahir di koloni palabuan syracuse sisilia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimides ku sababaraha ahli sajarah matematika dianggap salaku saurang ahli matematika nu luar biasa dina mangsa baheula carl friedrich gauss nganggap archimides dua urang nu luar salilana nu sejenna isaac newton
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimedes jadi kawentar ku hasil usahana dina mempertahankeun syracuse tina serangan tentara roma dina perang punic kadua
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimides dianggap ngusir romawi di basisir make mesin perang jieunan sorangan nu mampu mindahkeun kapal tur babawaanna ku cara ngadorong tali sarta manggihkeun prinsip densitas jeung gaya apung nu disebut oge prinsip archimedes waktu keur mandi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina sajarahna archimides terus lumpat ka jalan bakat ku bungah kana pamanggih lumpat bari teu dibaju bari ngagorowok eureka kuring geus manggihkeun
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimides diaku oge nu manggihkeun odometer dina perang punic kahiji
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pamanggihna dipake keur pertahanan militer syracuse ngalawan invasi roma disebut cakar archimides
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is said that he prevented one roman attack on syracuse by using a large array of mirrors speculated to have been highly polished shields to reflect sunlight onto the attacking ships causing them to catch fire
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this popular legend has been tested many times since the renaissance and often discredited as it seemed the ships would have had to have been virtually motionless and very close to shore for them to ignite an unlikely scenario during a battle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a group at mit have performed their own tests and concluded that the mirror weapon was a possibility although later tests of their system showed it to be ineffective in conditions that more closely matched the described siege
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimedes also has been credited with improving the accuracy and range of the catapult
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimedes was killed by a roman soldier during the sack of syracuse during the second punic war despite orders from the roman general marcellus that he was not to be harmed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the greeks said that he was killed while drawing an equation in the sand engrossed in his diagram and impatient with being interrupted he is said to have muttered his famous last words before being slain by an enraged roman soldier un uou tous kukaous tapatte don't disturb my circles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the phrase is often given in latin as noli turbare circulos meos but there is no direct evidence that archimedes ever uttered these words
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this story was sometimes told to contrast the greek high mindedness with roman ham handedness however it should be noted that archimedes designed the siege engines that devastated a substantial roman invasion force so his death may have been out of retribution ; marcellus had the soldier executed for the deed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in creativity and insight archimedes exceeded any other european mathematician prior to the european renaissance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in a civilization with an awkward numeral system and a language in which a myriad literally ten thousand meant infinity he invented a positional numeral system and used it to write numbers up to 10 64
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he devised a heuristic method based on statistics to do private calculation that we would classify today as integral calculus but then presented rigorous geometric proofs for his results
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to what extent he actually had a correct version of integral calculus is debatable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he proved that the ratio of a circle's perimeter to its diameter is the same as the ratio of the circle's area to the square of the radius
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he did not call this ratio n but he gave a procedure to approximate it to arbitrary accuracy and gave an approximation of it as between 3 + 10/71 approximately 3.1408 and 3 + 1/7 approximately 3.1429
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was the first greek mathematician to introduce mechanical curves those traced by a moving point as legitimate objects of study
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he proved that the area enclosed by a parabola and a straight line is 4/3 the area of a triangle with equal base and height
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see the illustration below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the base is any secant line not necessarily orthogonal to the parabola's axis the same base means the same horizontal component of the length of the base horizontal means orthogonal to the axis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: height means the length of the segment parallel to the axis from the vertex to the base
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the vertex must be so placed that the two horizontal distances mentioned in the illustration are equal <div style="float:right;padding:5px;text-align:center"> in the process he calculated the earliest known example of a geometric progression with the ratio 1/4 if the first term in this series is the area of the triangle in the illustration then the second is the sum of the areas of two triangles whose bases are the two smaller secant lines in the illustration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: essentially this paragraph summarizes the proof
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimedes also gave a quite different proof of nearly the same proposition by a method using infinitesimals see how archimedes used infinitesimals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he proved that the area and volume of the sphere are in the same ratio to the area and volume of a circumscribed straight cylinder a result he was so proud of that he made it his epitaph
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimedes is probably also the first mathematical physicist on record and the best before galileo and newton
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he invented the field of statics enunciated the law of the lever the law of equilibrium of fluids and the law of buoyancy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he famously discovered the latter when he was asked to determine whether a crown had been made of pure gold or gold adulterated with silver he realized that the rise in the water level when it was immersed would be equal to the volume of the crown and the decrease in the weight of the crown would be in proportion he could then compare those with the values of an equal weight of pure gold
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was the first to identify the concept of center of gravity and he found the centers of gravity of various geometric figures assuming uniform density in their interiors including triangles paraboloids and hemispheres
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: using only ancient greek geometry he also gave the equilibrium positions of floating sections of paraboloids as a function of their height a feat that would be taxing to a modern physicist using calculus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: apart from general physics he was also an astronomer and cicero writes that the roman consul marcellus brought two devices back to rome from the ransacked city of syracuse
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one device mapped the sky on a sphere and the other predicted the motions of the sun and the moon and the planets i.e an orrery
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he credits thales and eudoxus for constructing these devices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for some time this was assumed to be a legend of doubtful nature but the discovery of the antikythera mechanism has changed the view of this issue and it is indeed probable that archimedes possessed and constructed such devices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pappus of alexandria writes that archimedes had written a practical book on the construction of such spheres entitled on sphere making
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archimedes works were not widely recognized even in antiquity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he and his contemporaries probably constitute the peak of greek mathematical rigour
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the middle ages the mathematicians who could understand archimedes work were few and far between
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many of his works were lost when the library of alexandria was burnt twice and survived only in latin or arabic translations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a result his mechanical method was lost until around 1900 after the arithmetization of analysis had been carried out successfully
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: we can only speculate about the effect that the method would have had on the development of calculus had it been known in the 16th and 17th centuries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppose x is a discrete random variable whose values lie in the set { 0 1 2 } or in the set { 1 2 3 } the probability distribution of x is memoryless precisely if for any x y in { 0 1 2 } or in { 1 2 3 } as the case may be we have it can readily be shown that the only probability distributions that enjoy this discrete memorylessness are geometric distributions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are the distributions of the number of independent bernoulli trials needed to get one success with a fixed probability p of success on each trial
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example suppose a die is thrown as many times as it takes to get a 1 so that the probability of success on each trial is 1/6 and the random variable x is the number of times the die must be thrown
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then x has a geometric distribution and the conditional probability that the die must be thrown at least four more times to get a 1 given that it has already been thrown 10 times without a 1 appearing is no different from the original probability that the die would be thrown at least four times
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in effect the random process does not remember how many failures have occurred so far
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: memorylessness is often misunderstood by students taking courses on probability the fact that p(x > 16 | x > 12 = p(x > 4 does not mean that the events x > 16 and x > 12 are independent i.e it does not mean that p(x > 16 | x > 12 = p(x > 16
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to summarize memorlessness of the probability distribution of the number of trials x until the first success means the only difference between this and the discrete version is that instead of requiring s and t to be positive or in some cases nonnegative integers thus achieving discreteness we allow them to be real numbers that are not necessarily integers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it can be shown that the only probability distributions that enjoy this continuous memorylessness are the sebaran eksponensial
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in an ethene monomer one electron pair is held securely between the two carbons in a sigma bond
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the other is more loosely held in a pi bond
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the free radical uses one electron from the pi bond to form a more stable bond with the carbon atom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the other electron returns to the second carbon atom turning the whole molecule in to another radical
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: propagation is the rapid reaction of this radicalised ethene molecule with another ethene monomer and the subsequent repetition to create the repeating chain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: termination occurs when a radical reacts in a way that prevents further propagation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most common method of termination is by coupling where two radical species react with each other forming a single molecule
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another less common method of termination is disproportionation where two radicals meet but instead of coupling they exchange a proton which gives two terminated chains one saturated and the other with a terminal double bond
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: free radical addition polymerization of ethylene must take place at high temperatures and pressures approximately 300°c and 2000 at
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while most other free radical polymerizations do not require such extreme temperatures and pressures they do tend to lack control
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one effect of this lack of control is a high degree of branching
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also as termination occurs randomly when two chains collide it is impossible to control the length of individual chains
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a newer method of polymerization similar to free radical but allowing more control involves the ziegler natta catalyst
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the problem of branching occurs during propagation when a chain curls back on itself and breaks leaving irregular chains sprouting from the main carbon backbone
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: branching makes the polymers less dense and results in low tensile strength and melting points
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: developed by karl ziegler and giulio natta in the 1950s ziegler natta catalysts triethylaluminium in the presence of a metal iv chloride largely solved this problem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: instead of a free radical reaction the initial ethene monomer inserts between the aluminium atom and one of the ethyl groups in the catalyst
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the polymer is then able to grow out from the aluminium atom and results in almost totally unbranched chains
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the new catalysts the tacticity of the polypropene chain the alignment of alkyl groups was also able to be controlled
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: different metal chlorides allowed the selective production of each form i.e syndiotactic isotactic and atactic polymer chains could be selectively created
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however there were further complications to be solved
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the ziegler natta catalyst was poisoned or damaged then the chain stopped growing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also ziegler natta monomers have to be small and it was still impossible to control the molecular mass of the polymer chains
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: again new catalysts the metallocenes were developed to tackle these problems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: due to their structure they have less premature chain termination and branching
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other forms of addition polymerization include cationic and anionic polymerization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while not used to a large extent in industry yet due to stringent reaction conditions such as lack of water and oxygen these methods provide ways to polymerize some monomers that cannot be polymerized by free radical methods such as polypropylene
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cationic and anionic mechanisms are also more ideally suited for living polymerizations although free radical living polymerizations have also been developed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: trees occur in many diverse orders and families of plants and thus show a wide variety of growth form leaf types and shapes bark reproductive organs etc the earliest trees were tree ferns and horsetails which grew in vast forests in the carboniferous period tree ferns still survive but the only surviving horsetails are not of tree form
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later in the triassic period conifers ginkgos cycads and other gymnosperms appeared and subsequently flowering plants in the cretaceous period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most species of trees today are flowering plants and conifers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the list below gives some examples of well known trees and how they are typically classified
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the component parts of a tree are the roots trunk(s branches twigs and leaves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tree stems consist mainly of support and transport tissues xylem and phloem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: wood consists of xylem cells and bark is primarily made of phloem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: trees may be broadly grouped into exogenous and endogenous trees according to the way in which their stem diameter grows
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: exogenous trees which comprise the great majority of modern trees all conifers and all broadleaf trees grow by the addition of new wood outwards immediately under the bark
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: endogenous trees mainly in the monocotyledons e.g palms grow by addition of new material inwards
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as an exogenous tree grows it creates growth rings
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in temperate climates these are commonly visible due to changes in the rate of growth with the temperature variation over the year
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these can be counted to determine the age of the tree and used to date cores or even wood taken from trees in the past this is known as the science of dendrochronology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in tropical climates with near constant climate growth is continuous and does not form distinct rings so age determination is impossible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: age determination is also impossible in endogenous trees
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the roots of a tree are generally embedded in earth providing anchorage for the above ground biomass and absorbing water and nutrients from the soil
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: above ground the trunk gives height to the leaf bearing branches aiding in competition with other plant species for sunlight
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in many trees the arrangement of the branches optimizes exposure of the leaves to sunlight
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: not all trees have all the plant organs mentioned above
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for examples most palm trees are not branched the saguaro cactus of north america has no functional leaves tree ferns do not have bark etc based on their rough shape and size all of these are nonetheless generally regarded as trees
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: indeed sometimes size is the most important consideration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a plant form that is similar to a tree but generally having smaller multiple trunks and or branches that arise near the ground is called a shrub
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however no sharp differentiation between shrubs and trees is possible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: given their small size bonsai plants would not technically be trees but one should not confuse reference to the form of a species with the size or shape of individual specimens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a spruce seedling does not fit the definition of a tree but all spruces are trees
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bamboos by contrast do show most of the characteristics of trees yet are perhaps strangely rarely called trees
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a small group of trees growing together is called a grove or copse and a landscape covered by a large area of trees is called a forest
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: several biotopes are defined largely by the trees that inhabit them for example rainforest and taiga see ecozones
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: large but scattered trees with grassland usually grazed or burned over periodically in between is called savanna
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: patologi tina basa yunani pathos ngarasa nyeri menderita jeung logos elmu ngeunaan tingali oge ologi nyaeta studi ngeunaan proses nu midasar panyakit jeung wangun sejen tinu gering kahenteunormalan anu ngabahayakeun atawa disfungsi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: patologi minangka cabang elmu pangaweruh saterusna ngawangun dasar pamikiran elmu pangaweruh di satukangeun praktek medis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the primary goal of pathology is the study of the four main aspects of a disease
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathologists are physicians whose residency varies from 3-4 years followed by fellowship training for most
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because the public rarely meets pathologists their work is not well understood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathology is a large and diverse field that allows a pathologist to participate in multiple areas of the field or focus their scope to a specific area
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: essential to everyday surgeries pathologists are responsible for processing and reporting on all specimens generated during a given surgery
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tissue samples are taken from the submitted specimens stained and processed for microscopic evaluation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: microscopic examination searches for disease of any type and this information is returned to the surgeon via a pathology report
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathologists are also responsible for laboratory specimens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they along with medical technologists process specimens at medical laboratories for interpretations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in other words patients should know that what their doctor calls a laboratory result is not a number generated by a black box
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: instead it is the interpretation of the value by a pathologist or a technologist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is also important to understand that a different laboratory might produce a different value on the same specimen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathologists are also called upon to perform autopsies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: autopsies represent less than 5% of the workload of a typical modern pathologist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there exists a subspecialty in pathology that allows for the training of medical examiners who wish to pursue forensics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathologists usually do not see patients but do on occassion such as when performing bone marrow biopsies and aspirates or fine needle aspirations of superficial nodules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus it is best considered a form of diagnostic medicine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition to the diagnosis of disease including cancer and the administration of medical laboratories pathologists often participate in the teaching of medical students pathology is a core course in the medical curriculum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathologists express their opinion as a pathology report addressed to the doctor requesting it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since pathologists most often communicate with other doctors they are sometimes nicknamed the doctor's doctor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathology is often considered the most scientific branch of medicine because of the available avenues of research involving human material
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: finally the circulation of laboratory data is a central issue in medical informatics and the current tendency towards electronic medical records
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the techniques used most often in the study of the disease process and hence diagnosis are
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the united states pathologists are medical doctors md or doctors of osteopathic medicine do that have completed a four year undergraduate program four years of medical school training and three or four years of postgraduate training in the form of a pathology residency
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: training may be within two primary specialties as recognized by the american board of pathology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the american board of oral and maxillofacial pathology certifies dentistry doctors not medical doctors to practice this sub specialty of pathology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathological is used to describe a person's actions in such a way as to credit the action to a disease process e.g pathological purchasing or pathological consumption pathological narcissism pathological liar pathological gambling pathological jealousy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathological is also used casually to signify an abnormal state e.g a pathological attitude or a pathological woman hater
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pathological is also used in mathematics physics and statistics to describe an exceptionally or awkwardly or inconveniently atypical example or set of data often one which does not abide by rules or succumb to treatment that other similar cases usually do forensic engineers often use the term to describe the underlying causes of distress in structures or machinery in order to specify repairs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: heunteu saperti dina theory of mechanics nu nangtukeun harti pasti tina saperti dina watesan gawe jeung gaya dina tiori probabiliti nyobaan keur ngitung dina notasi probable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: probability theory as applied to observations was largely a nineteenth century development
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gambling shows that there has been an interest in quantifying the ideas of probability for millennia but exact mathematical descriptions of use in these types of problems only arose much later
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the doctrine of probabilities dates as far back as pierre de fermat and blaise pascal 1654
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: christiaan huygens 1657 gave the first scientific treatment of the subject
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: jakob bernoulli's ars conjectandi posthumous 1713 and abraham de moivre's doctrine of chances 1718 treated the subject as a branch of mathematics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the theory of errors may be traced back to roger cotes's opera miscellanea posthumous 1722 but a memoir prepared by simpson in 1755 printed 1756 first applied the theory to the discussion of errors of observation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the reprint 1757 of this memoir lays down the axioms that positive and negative errors are equally probable and that there are certain assignable limits within which all errors may be supposed to fall continuous errors are discussed and a probability curve is given
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pierre simon laplace 1774 made the first attempt to deduce a rule for the combination of observations from the principles of the theory of probabilities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he represented the law of probability of errors by a curve being 0 3 the area enclosed is 1 it being certain that an error exists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he deduced a formula for the mean of three observations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he also gave 1781 a formula for the law of facility of error a term due to lagrange 1774 but one which led to unmanageable equations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: daniel bernoulli 1778 introduced the principle of the maximum product of the probabilities of a system of concurrent errors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the method of least squares is due to adrien marie legendre 1805 who introduced it in his nouvelles methodes pour la determination des orbites des cometes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in ignorance of legendre's contribution an irish american writer robert adrain editor of the analyst 1808 first deduced the law of facility of error : the probable error of a single observation is well known
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the nineteenth century authors on the general theory included laplace lacroix 1816 littrow 1833 adolphe quetelet 1853 richard dedekind 1860 helmert 1872 laurent 1873 liagre didion and pearson
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: augustus de morgan and george boole improved the exposition of the theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on the geometric side see integral geometry contributors to the educational times were influential miller crofton mccoll wolstenholme watson and artemas martin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is essentially one set of mathematical rules for manipulating probability these rules are listed under formalization of probability below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are other rules for quantifying uncertainty such as the dempster shafer theory and fuzzy logic but those are essentially different and not compatible with the laws of probability as they are usually understood however there is ongoing debate over what exactly the rules apply to this is the topic of probability interpretations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the general idea of probability is often divided into two related concepts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: saperti teori sejen tiori probabiliti is a representation of probabilistic concepts in formal terms that is in terms that can be considered separately from their meaning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these formal terms are manipulated by the rules of mathematics and logic and any results are then interpreted or translated back into the problem domain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there have been at least two successful attempts to formalize probability namely the kolmogorov formulation and the cox formulation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in kolmogorov's formulation sets are interpreted as events and probability itself as a measure on a class of sets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in cox's formulation probability is taken as a primitive that is not further analyzed and the emphasis is on constructing a consistent assignment of probability values to propositions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in both cases the laws of probability are the same except for technical details
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the probability of an event is generally represented as a real number between 0 and 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an impossible event has a probability of exactly 0 and a certain event has a probability of 1 but the converses are not always true probability 0 events are not always impossible nor probability 1 events certain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the rather subtle distinction between certain and probability 1 is treated at greater length in the article on almost surely
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most probabilities that occur in practice are numbers between 0 and 1 indicating the event's position on the continuum between impossibility and certainty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the closer an event's probability is to 1 the more likely it is to occur
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example if two events are assumed equally probable such as a flipped coin landing heads up or tails up we can express the probability of each event as 1 in 2 or equivalently 50% or 1/2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: probabilities are equivalently expressed as odds which is the ratio of the probability of one event to the probability of all other events
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the odds of heads up for the tossed coin are 1/2)/(1 1/2 which is equal to 1/1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is expressed as 1 to 1 odds and often written 1:1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: odds a:b for some event are equivalent to probability a/(a+b
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example 1:1 odds are equivalent to probability 1/2 and 3:2 odds are equivalent to probability 3/5
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there remains the question of exactly what can be assigned probability and how the numbers so assigned can be used this is the question of probability interpretations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are some who claim that probability can be assigned to any kind of an uncertain logical proposition this is the bayesian interpretation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are others who argue that probability is properly applied only to propositions concerning sequences of repeated experiments or sampling from a large population this is the frequentist interpretation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are several other interpretations which are variations on one or the other of those or which have less acceptance at present
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a probability distribution is a function that assigns probabilities to events or propositions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for any set of events or propositions there are many ways to assign probabilities so the choice of one distribution or another is equivalent to making different assumptions about the events or propositions in question
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are several equivalent ways to specify a probability distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: perhaps the most common is to specify a probability density function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then the probability of an event or proposition is obtained by integrating the density function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the distribution function may also be specified directly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in one dimension the distribution function is called the cumulative distribution function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: probability distributions can also be specified via moments or the characteristic function or in still other ways
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a distribution is called a discrete distribution if it is defined on a countable discrete set such as a subset of the integers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a distribution is called a continuous distribution if it has a continuous distribution function such as a polynomial or exponential function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most distributions of practical importance are either discrete or continuous but there are examples of distributions which are neither
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: important discrete distributions include the discrete sebaran seragam sebaran poisson sebaran binomial the negative binomial distribution and the maxwell boltzmann distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sebaran kontinyu anu penting nyaeta sebaran normal sebaran gamma sebaran t student sarta sebaran eksponensial
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: probability axioms form the basis for mathematical probability theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: calculation of probabilities can often be determined using combinatorics or by applying the axioms directly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: probability applications include even more than statistics which is usually based on the idea of probability distributions and the central limit theorem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to give a mathematical meaning to probability consider flipping a fair coin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: intuitively the probability that heads will come up on any given coin toss is obviously 50% but this statement alone lacks mathematical rigor certainly while we might expect that flipping such a coin 10 times will yield 5 heads and 5 tails there is no guarantee that this will occur it is possible for example to flip 10 heads in a row
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: what then does the number 50% mean in this context
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one approach is to use the law of large numbers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this case we assume that we can perform any number of coin flips with each coin flip being independent that is to say the outcome of each coin flip is unaffected by previous coin flips
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if we perform n trials coin flips and let n h be the number of times the coin lands heads then we can for any n consider the ratio n h n
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as n gets larger and larger we expect that in our example the ratio n h n will get closer and closer to 1/2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this allows us to define the probability pr(h of flipping heads as the mathematical limit as n approaches infinity of this sequence of ratios in other words by saying that the probability of heads is 1/2 we mean that if we flip our coin often enough eventually the number of heads over the number of total flips will become arbitrarily close to 1/2 and will then stay at least as close to 1/2 for as long as we keep performing additional coin flips
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the a priori aspect of this approach to probability is sometimes troubling when applied to real world situations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example in the play rosencrantz and guildenstern are dead by tom stoppard a character flips a coin which keeps coming up heads over and over again a hundred times
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he can't decide whether this is just a random event after all it is possible although unlikely that a fair coin would give this result or whether his assumption that the coin is fair is at fault
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the difficulty of probability calculations lie in determining the number of possible events counting the occurrences of each event counting the total number of possible events
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: especially difficult is drawing meaningful conclusions from the probabilities calculated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an amusing probability riddle the monty hall problem demonstrates the pitfalls nicely
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to learn more about the basics of probability theory see the article on probability axioms and the article on bayes theorem that explains the use of conditional probabilities in case where the occurrence of two events is related
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a major effect of probability theory on everyday life is in risk assessment and in trade on commodity markets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: governments typically apply probability methods in environment regulation where it is called pathway analysis and are often measuring well being using methods that are stochastic in nature and choosing projects to undertake based on their perceived probable effect on the population as a whole statistically
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is not correct to say that statistics are involved in the modelling itself as typically the assessments of risk are one time and thus require more fundamental probability models e.g the probability of another 9/11
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a law of small numbers tends to apply to all such choices and perception of the effect of such choices which makes probability measures a political matter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a good example is the effect of the perceived probability of any widespread middle east conflict on oil prices which have ripple effects in the economy as a whole
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an assessment by a commodity trade that a war is more likely vs less likely sends prices up or down and signals other traders of that opinion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: accordingly the probabilities are not assessed independently nor necessarily very rationally
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the theory of behavioral finance emerged to describe the effect of such groupthink on pricing on policy and on peace and conflict
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it can reasonably be said that the discovery of rigorous methods to assess and combine probability assessments has had a profound effect on modern society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a good example is the application of game theory itself based strictly on probability to the cold war and the mutual assured destruction doctrine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: accordingly it may be of some importance to most citizens to understand how odds and probability assessments are made and how they contribute to reputations and to decisions especially in a democracy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another significant application of probability theory in everyday life is reliability
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many consumer products such as automobiles and consumer electronics utilize reliability theory in the design of the product in order to reduce the probability of failure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the the probability of failure is also closely associated with the product's warranty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sacara sajarah widang utama dina matematik ningkat kacida keur digunakeun dina widang perdagangan ngukur taneuh jeung keur prediksi kajadian astronomi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hal ieu merlukan tilu hal anu raket pakuat pakaitna nu mangrupa pembagian dina widang matematik nyaeta struktur ruang jeung parobahan.pangajaran struktur dimimitian ku numbers firstly the familiar natural numbers and integers and their arithmetical operations which are recorded in elementary algebra
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the deeper properties of whole numbers are studied in number theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the investigation of methods to solve equations leads to the field of abstract algebra which among other things studies rings and fields structures that generalize the properties possessed by the familiar numbers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the physically important concept of vector generalized to vector spaces and studied in linear algebra belongs to the two branches of structure and space.the study of space originates with geometry first the euclidean geometry and trigonometry of familiar three dimensional space but later also generalized to non euclidean geometries which play a central role in general relativity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: several long standing questions about ruler and compass constructions were finally settled by galois theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the modern fields of differential geometry and algebraic geometry generalize geometry in different directions differential geometry emphasizes the concepts of coordinate system smoothness and direction while in algebraic geometry geometrical objects are described as solution sets of polynomial equations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: group theory investigates the concept of symmetry abstractly and provides a link between the studies of space and structure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: topology connects the study of space and the study of change by focusing on the concept of continuity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: understanding and describing change in measurable quantities is the common theme of the natural sciences and calculus was developed as a most useful tool for doing just that
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the central concept used to describe a changing variable is that of a function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many problems lead quite naturally to relations between a quantity and its rate of change and the methods to solve these are studied in the field of differential equations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the numbers used to represent continuous quantities are the real numbers and the detailed study of their properties and the properties of real valued functions is known as real analysis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for several reasons it is convenient to generalise to the complex numbers which are studied in complex analysis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: functional analysis focuses attention on typically infinite dimensional spaces of functions laying the groundwork for quantum mechanics among many other things
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many phenomena in nature can be described by dynamical systems and chaos theory deals with the fact that many of these systems exhibit unpredictable yet deterministic behavior
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in order to clarify and investigate the foundations of mathematics the fields of set theory mathematical logic and model theory were developed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when computers were first conceived several essential theoretical concepts were shaped by mathematicians leading to the fields of computability theory computational complexity theory information theory and algorithmic information theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many of these questions are now investigated in theoretical computer science
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: discrete mathematics is the common name for those fields of mathematics useful in computer science
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: politics predates human society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most primates live in groups and form dominance hierarchies individuals with greater hierarchical status tend to displace those ranked lower from space from food and from mating opportunities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus higher status individuals tend to have greater reproductive success by mating more often and having more resources to invest in the survival of offspring
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these hierarchies are not fixed and depend on any number of changing factors among them are age gender intelligence and aggressiveness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: status may also be affected by the ability to marshal the support of others
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: indeed the need to maintain social position and social knowledge may be an impetus for the evolution of larger brains in humans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early human polities organized groups include families clans and tribes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: vg childe describes the transformation of human society that took place around 6000 bce as an urban revolution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: among the features of this new type of civilization are institutional social stratification(dominance hierarchy non agricultural specialised crafts including priests and lawyers taxation and writing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all of which require densely populated settlements cities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while the word politics is derived from the greek word for city polis it should be remembered that politics happens in every group undertaking
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: corporate religious academic and every other polity especially those constrained by limited resources contain dominance hierarchies and therefore politics.politics is most often studied in the public administrative context
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the oldest form of government grew out of tribal organization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rule by elders was supplanted by monarchy an arrangement where a single family dominated the political affairs of a polity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: monarchies have existed in one form or another throughout human history
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: greeks developed democracy as a means of governance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: athenian direct democracy limited citizenship to free male landholders but demonstrated the viability of government by the governed albeit an educated leisure class
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the roman republic is credited with significant innovation in forms of government
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was the first bicameral legislative system which divided power between the patrician aristocracy and plebian general citizens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it also contained the beginnings of representative democracy having various officers selected for fixed terms by popular election
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: following the collapse of the roman empire europe reverted to feudal monarchy where the mailed fist ruled
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the renaissance the enlightenment and the industrial revolution each increased the availability of education and leisure to otherwise disenfranchised classes along with a desire to participate in governance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: karl marx argued that this process of political progress will not be complete until classes no longer exist and every person is the master of his own fate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: marx never imagined the juggernaut democratic capitalism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this analysis argues that progress i.e democratization increases with the rise of an educated population that has time to devote to activities beyond simple survival
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as noted power is the ability to impose ones will on another
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it implies a capacity for force i.e violence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more generally it can be considered the ability to change the liklihood of outcomes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ability to impose one's will on others is very often not a totally dependable policy option
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it comes in degrees thus we can speak of the degree to which we can change the liklihood of outcomes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in politics one of the most subtle and effective kinds of power does not involve overt violence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: instead it is the control of the agenda for deliberation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if you control what is considered proper for political discourse what our options are for policy choice you are indeed exercising real power
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: authority is the ability to wield the instruments of power
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its legitimacy is measured by the extent to which it receives support from the governed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: legitimacy is an attribute of government gained through the application of power in accordance with recognized or accepted standards or principles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a government is a body that has the ability to make and enforces rules or laws
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a government's power is influenced by authority and legitimacy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: politics may have a pejorative sense particularly when applied to the internal workings of institutions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: saying that a decision was reached for political reasons may hint that those reasons were more motivated by petty interests or influence peddling than by objective reasons or the common good
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at whatever scale politics is the rather imperfect way that people coordinate individual actions for mutual or strictly personal gain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: what distinguishes the political from the ethical or merely social is a much debated question
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most theorists would acknowledge that to be political a process has to involve at least some potential for use of force or violence politics is about conflict that is about much more than theory and fashion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to win a political conflict always implies that one has taken power away from one group or faction to give it to another
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most would also acknowledge that political conflict can easily degrade to zero sum games with little learned or settled by conflict other than who won and who lost lenin said politics was about who could do what to whom russian kto kogo for who whom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as political scientist harold lasswell said politics is who gets what when and how it also concerns how we resolve moral conflicts that are sufficiently serious that they constitute a risk of social disruption in which case commitment to a common process of arbitration or diplomacy tends to reduce violence usually viewed as a key goal of civilization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bernard crick is a major theorist of this view and also of the idea that politics is itself simply ethics done in public where public institutions can agree disagree or intervene to achieve a desirable culmination or comprehensive process result
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition to government journalists religious groups special interest groups and economic systems and conditions may all have influence on decisions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: therefore politics touches on all these subjects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the word itself is coined from the greek word for city polis hence the term politics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first expression of what politics means is found in hesoid where it is quoted how would men best dwell in cities and with what observances
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 1 paraphrased it would read how shall man order his ways
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for the greeks it was the application of reason to life
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: politics is an ordering of society by reason of attainment to some goal such as harmony among the social classes as in athens under solon or business and commerce or for war such as the doric communities of crete and sparta
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: authors of studies of politics have both reflected and influenced the political systems of the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: niccolo machiavelli wrote the prince an analysis of politics in a monarchy in 1513 while living in a monarchy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: karl marx and friedrich engels published the communist manifesto in 1848 a widely read and highly influential pamphlet that formed the basis for socialism and communism throughout the 19th and 20th centuries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: today much study of politics focuses on democracies and how their form affects the decisions they make
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other lines of political inquiry attempt to answer philosophical questions such as as well as being influenced by these weighty matters politics is also a social activity and as such it is subject to the whims of fashion as any other
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: diberekeun dua sebaran gabungan variabel random x jeung y sebaran kondisional probabiliti of y given x written y | x is the probability distribution of y when x is known to be a particular value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for discrete random variables the conditional probability mass function can be written as p(y = y | x = x
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from the definition of conditional probability this is where p x,y x y gives the joint distribution of x and y while p x x gives the marginal distribution for x the concept of the conditional distribution of a continuous random variable is not as intuitive as it might seem borel's paradox shows that conditional probability density functions need not be invariant under coordinate transformations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if for discrete random variables p(y = y | x = x = p(y = y for all x and y or for continuous random variables p y|x y | x = p y y for all x and y then y is said to be independent of x and this implies that x is also independent of y
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: seen as a function of y for given x p(y = y | x = x is a probability and so the sum over all y or integral if it is a density is 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: seen as a function of x for given y it is a likelihood so that the sum over all x need not be 1

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--muscle spindles are distributed throughout the muscles and provide sensory feedback information to the central nervous system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: skeletal muscle which involves muscles from the skeletal tissue is arranged in discrete groups examples of which include the biceps brachii
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is connected by tendons to processes of the skeleton
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in contrast smooth muscle occurs at various scales in almost every organ from the skin in which it controls erection of body hair to the blood vessels and digestive tract in which it controls the caliber of a lumen and peristalsis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are approximately 650 skeletal muscles in the human body see list of muscles of the human body
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: contrary to popular belief the number of muscle fibers cannot be increased through exercise instead the muscle cells simply get bigger
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is however believed that myofibrils have a limited capacity for growth through hypertrophy and will split if subject to increased demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ten types of muscle have significant differences
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however all but three use the movement of actin against myosin to create contraction and relaxation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in skeletal muscle contraction is stimulated by electrical impulses transmitted by the nerves the motor nerves and motoneurons in particular
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all skeletal muscle and many smooth muscle contractions are facilitated by the neurotransmitter acetylcholine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: muscular activity accounts for most of the body's energy consumption
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: muscles store energy for their own use in the form of glycogen which represents about 1% of their mass
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this can be rapidly converted to glucose when more energy is necessary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: vertebrates move muscles in response to voluntary and autonomic signals from the brain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: deep muscles superficial muscles muscles of the face and internal muscles all correspond with dedicated regions in the brain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition muscles react to reflexive nerve stimuli that do not always send signals all the way to the brain but most muscle activity is the result of complex interactions between various areas of the brain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nerves that control skeletal muscles in mammals correspond with neuron groups along the primary motor cortex of the brain's cerebral cortex
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: commands are routed though the basal ganglia and are modified by input from the cerebellum before being relayed through the pyramidal tract to the spinal cord and from there to the motor end plate at the muscles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: along the way feedback loops such as that of the extrapyramidal system contribute signals to influence muscle tone and response
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: deeper muscles such as those involved in posture often are controlled from nuclei in the brain stem and basal ganglia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometimes known as muscle memory the sense of where our bodies are in space is called proprioception the perception of body awareness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more easily demonstrated than explained proprioception is the unconscious awareness of where the various regions of the body are located at any one time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this can be demonstrated by anyone closing their eyes and waving their hand around
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: assuming proper proprioceptive function at no time will the person lose awareness of where the hand actually is even though it is not being detected by any of the other senses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: several areas in the brain coordinate movement and position with the feedback information gained from proprioception
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cerebellum and nucleus ruber in particular continuously sample position against movement and make minor corrections to assure a smooth projection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: exercise is often recommended as a means of improving motor skills fitness and muscle strength
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: exercise has several effects upon muscles connective tissue and bone and the nerves that stimulate the muscles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: various exercises require a predominance of certain muscle fiber utilization over another
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aerobic events which rely primarily on the aerobic system use a higher percentage of type i or slow-twitch muscle fibers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shorter events which rely on the anaerobic energy delivery system use predominantly type ii muscle fibers or fast-twitch muscle fibers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: humans are genetically predisposed with a larger percentage of one type of muscle group over another
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an individual born with a greater percentage of type i muscle fibers would theoretically be more adept at endurance events such as triathlons distance running and long cycling events whereas a human born with a greater percentage of type ii muscle fibers would be more likely to excel at anaerobic events such as a 200 meter dash or weight lifting
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :for more detail also see neuromuscular disease there are many diseases and conditions which cause a decrease in muscle mass known as atrophy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example diseases such as cancer and aids induce a body wasting syndrome called cachexia which is notable for the severe muscle atrophy seen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other syndromes or conditions which can induce skeletal muscle atrophy are congestive heart disease and liver disease
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during aging there is a gradual decrease in the ability to maintain skeletal muscle function and mass
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this condition is called sarcopenia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the exact cause of sarcopenia is unknown but it may be due to a combination of the gradual failure in the satellite cells which help to regenerate skeletal muscle fibers and a decrease in sensitivity to or the availability of critical secreted growth factors which are necessary to maintain muscle mass and satellite cell survival
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition to the simple loss of muscle mass atrophy or the age related decrease in muscle function sarcopenia there are other diseases which may be caused by structural defects in the muscle the dystrophies or by inflammatory reactions in the body directed against muscle the myopathies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: symptoms of muscle disease may include weakness or spasticity rigidity myoclonus twitching and myalgia muscle pain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: diagnostic procedures that may reveal muscular disorders include testing creatine kinase levels in the blood and electromyography measuring electrical activity in muscles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some cases muscle biopsy may be done to identify a myopathy as well as genetic testing to identify dna abnormalities associated with specific myopathies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: neuromuscular diseases are those that affect the muscles and or their nervous control
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in general problems with nervous control can cause spasticity or paralysis depending on the location and nature of the problem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a large proportion of neurological disorders leads to problems with movement ranging from cerebrovascular accident stroke and parkinson's disease to creutzfeldt jakob disease
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: depending on what definition of strongest is used many different muscles in the human body can be characterized as being the strongest in ordinary parlance muscular strength usually refers to the ability to exert a force on an external object for example lifting a weight
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by this definition the masseter or jaw muscle is the strongest
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 1992 guinness book of records records the achievement of a bite strength of 975 lbf 4337 n for two seconds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: what distinguishes the masseter is not anything special about the muscle itself but its advantage in working against a much shorter lever arm than other muscles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if strength refers to the force exerted by the muscle itself e.g on the place where it inserts into a bone then the strongest muscles are those with the largest cross sectional area at their belly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is because the tension exerted by an individual skeletal striated muscle fiber does not vary much either from muscle to muscle or with length
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each fiber can exert a force on the order of 0.3 micronewtons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by this definition the strongest muscle of the body is usually said to be the quadriceps femoris or the gluteus maximus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: again taking strength to mean only force in the physicist's sense and as contrasted with energy or power then a shorter muscle will be stronger pound for pound i.e by weight than a longer muscle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the uterus may be the strongest muscle by weight in the human body
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the time when an infant is delivered the human uterus weighs about 40 oz 1.1 kg
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during childbirth the uterus exerts 25 to 100 lbf 100 to 400 n of downward force with each contraction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the external muscles of the eye are conspicuously large and strong in relation to the small size and weight of the eyeball
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is frequently said that they are the strongest muscles for the job they have to do and are sometimes claimed to be 100 times stronger than they need to be eye movements however probably do need to be exceptionally fast
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the unexplained statement that the tongue is the strongest muscle in the body appears frequently in lists of surprising facts but it is difficult to find any definition of strength that would make this statement true
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: note that the tongue consists of sixteen muscles not one
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the tongue may possibly be the strongest muscle at birth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the heart has a claim to being the muscle that performs the largest quantity of physical work in the course of a lifetime
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: estimates of the power output of the human heart range from 1 to 5 watts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is much less than the maximum power output of other muscles for example the quadriceps can produce over 100 watts but only for a few minutes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the heart does its work continuously over an entire lifetime without pause and thus can outwork other muscles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an output of one watt continuously for seventy years yields a total work output of 2 to 3 x10 9 joules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the efficiency of human muscle has been measured in the context of rowing and cycling at 14% to 27%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the efficiency is defined as the ratio of mechanical work done to the total energy output heat plus work
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to a recent study published in 1999 specialized forms of skeletal and cardiac muscles predated the divergence of the vertebrate arthropod evolutionary line
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this indicates that these types of muscle developed in a common ancestor sometime before 700 million years ago mya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: vertebrate smooth muscle smooth muscle found in humans was found to have evolved independently from the skeletal and cardiac muscles.-->
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the middle lamella is laid first formed from the cell plate during cytokenesis and the primary cell wall is then expanded inside the middle lamella
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the actual structure of the cell wall is not clearly defined and several models exist the covalently linked cross model the tether model the diffuse layer model and the stratified layer model are to name a few
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the primary cell wall can be defined as composed of cellulose microfibrils aligned at all angles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: microfibrils are held together by hydrogen bonds to provide a high tensile strength
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cells are held together and share the gelatinous membrane called the middle lamella which contains magnesium and calcium pectates salts of pectic acid
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cells interact though plasmodesma(ta which are inter connecting channels of cytoplasm that connect to the protoplasts of adjacent cells across the cell wall
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some plants and cell types after a maximum size or point in development has been reached a secondary wall is constructed between the plant cell and primary wall
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unlike the primary wall the microfibrils are aligned mostly in the same direction and with each additional layer the orientation changes slightly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cells with secondary cell walls are rigid
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cell to cell communication is possible through pits in the secondary cell wall that allow plasmodesma to connect cells through the secondary cell walls
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the major carbohydrates making up the primary cell wall are cellulose hemicellulose and pectin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cellulose microfibrils are linked via hemicellulosic tethers to form the cellulose hemicellulose network which is embedded in the pectin matrix
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: plant cells walls also incorporate a number of proteins the most abundant include hydroxyproline rich glycoproteins hrgp also called the extensins the arabinogalactan proteins agp the glycine rich proteins grps and the proline rich proteins prps
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the exception of glycine rich proteins all the previously mentioned proteins are glycosylated and contain hydroxyproline hyp
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each class of glycoprotein is defined by a characteristic highly repetitive protein sequence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: chimeric proteins contain two or more different domains each with a sequence from a different class of glycoprotein
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most cell wall proteins are cross linked to the cell wall and may have structural functions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: secondary cell walls may contain lignin and suberin making the walls rigid
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the relative composition of carbohydrates secondary compounds and protein varies between plants and between the cell type and age
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: like plants algae have cell walls sendbusch 2003
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: algal cell walls contain cellulose and a variety of glycoproteins
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the inclusion of additional polysaccharides in algal cells walls is used as a feature for algal taxonomy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the group of algae known as the diatoms synthesise their cell walls also known as frustules or valves from silicic acid specifically orthosilicic acid h 4 sio 4 ).
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the acid is polymerised intra cellularly then the wall is extruded to protect the cell
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: significantly relative to the organic cell walls produced by other groups silica frustules require less energy to synthesize approximately 8% potentially a major saving on the overall cell energy budget raven 1983
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cell walls of bacteria are primarily used for protection against hostile environments or in the case of pathogenic bacteria against the immune system of the host
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they contain peptidoglycan which can be made visible in gram positive bacteria by gram staining
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cell walls of bacteria are also vital for containing the high osmotic pressure inside bacterial cells caused by the high concentration of solutes in the cytoplasm
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this pressure can often be as high as 15 atmospheres
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many antibiotics including penicillin and its derivatives target the cell wall of bacteria
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cell walls of archaea are not made of peptidoglycan but some archaea may contain pseudopeptidoglycan which is composed of n acetyltalosaminuronic acid instead of n acetyl muramic acid in peptidoglycan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: not all species of fungi have cell walls but in those that do the cell walls are composed of cellulose glucosamine and chitin the same carbohydrate that gives strength to the exoskeletons of insects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they serve a similar purpose to those of plant cells giving fungal cells rigidity and strength to hold their shape and preventing osmotic lysis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it also limits the entry of molecules that may be toxic to the fungus like plant produced and synthetic fungicides
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the composition properties and form of the fungal cell wall change during the cell cycle and depend on growth conditions.-->
lines.name: Sundanese
