lines.value: entropi teh minangka nu jadi ukuran tingkat acak ieu saperti anu diusulkeun ku shannon dina makalah " a mathematical theory of communication nu medar dina taun 1948 shannon nawarkeun hiji definisi entropi anu nyumponan asumsi asumsi yen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: claude e shannon defines entropy in terms of a discrete random event x with possible states or outcomes 1...n as where k is a constant and is really just a choice of measurement units
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shannon defined a measure of entropy h = − p 1 log 2 p 1 − … − p n log 2 p n ) that when applied to an information source could determine the minimum channel capacity required to reliably transmit the source as encoded binary digits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the formula can be derived by calculating the mathematical expectation of the amount of information contained in a digit from the information source
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shannon's entropy measure came to be taken as a measure of the uncertainty about the realization of a random variable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it thus served as a proxy capturing the concept of information contained in a message as opposed to the portion of the message that is strictly determined hence predictable by inherent structures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example redundancy in language structure or statistical properties relating to the occurrence frequencies of letter or word pairs triplets etc see markov chain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shannon's definition of entropy is closely related to thermodynamic entropy as defined by physicists and many chemists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: boltzmann and gibbs did considerable work on statistical thermodynamics which became the inspiration for adopting the word entropy in information theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are relationships between thermodynamic and informational entropy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in fact in the view of jaynes 1957 thermodynamics should be seen as an application of shannon's information theory the thermodynamic entropy is interpreted as being an estimate of the amount of further shannon information needed to define the detailed microscopic state of the system that remains uncommunicated by a description solely in terms of the macroscopic variables of classical thermodynamics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see article maxent thermodynamics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly maxwell's demon reverses thermodynamic entropy with information but if it is itself bound by the laws of thermodynamics getting rid of that information exactly balances out the thermodynamic gain the demon would otherwise achieve
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is important to remember that entropy is a quantity defined in the context of a probabilistic model for a data source
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: independent fair coin flips have an entropy of 1 bit per flip
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a source that always generates a long string of a's has an entropy of 0 since the next character will always be an a
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the entropy rate of a data source means the average number of bits per symbol needed to encode it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: empirically it seems that entropy of english text is between 1.1 and 1.6 bits per character though clearly that will vary from text source to text source
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: experiments with human predictors show an information rate of 1.1 or 1.6 bits per character depending on the experimental setup the ppm compression algorithm can achieve a compression ratio of 1.5 bits per character
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from the preceding example note the following points a common way to define entropy for text is based on the markov model of text
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for an order 0 source each character is selected independent of the last characters the binary entropy is : as the previous character s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for a second order markov source the entropy rate is note the b in b ary entropy is the number of different symbols of the ideal alphabet which is being used as the standard yardstick to measure source alphabets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in information theory two symbols are necessary and sufficient for an alphabet to be able to encode information therefore the default is to let b = 2 binary entropy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus the entropy of the source alphabet with its given empiric probability distribution is a number equal to the number possibly fractional of symbols of the ideal alphabet with an optimal probability distribution necessary to encode for each symbol of the source alphabet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also note that optimal probability distribution here means a uniform distribution a source alphabet with n symbols has the highest possible entropy for an alphabet with n symbols when the probability distribution of the alphabet is uniform
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this optimal entropy turns out to be [01] for all i = 1 …, n and p 1 + … + p n = 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: remark that the function solely depends on the probability distribution not the alphabet 2 for all positive integers n h satisfies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a source alphabet encountered in practice should be found to have a probability distribution which is less than optimal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the source alphabet has n symbols then it can be compared to an optimized alphabet with n symbols whose probability distribution is uniform
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ratio of the entropy of the source alphabet with the entropy of its optimized version is the efficiency of the source alphabet which can be expressed as a percentage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this implies that the efficiency of a source alphabet with n symbols can be defined simply as being equal to its n ary entropy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also redundancy information theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the entropy was given as a definition it does not need to be derived
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on the other hand a derivation can be given which gives a sense of the motivation for the definition as well as the link to thermodynamic entropy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: q given a roulette with n pockets which are all equally likely to be landed on by the ball what is the probability of obtaining a distribution a 1 , a 2 , …, a n ) where a i is the number of times pocket i was landed on and is the number of all possible combinations of outcomes for the set of p events
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: q and what is the entropy

lines.value: a the entropy of the distribution is obtained from the logarithm of w so the entropy is and the term 1 − n can be dropped since it is a constant independent of the p x distribution

lines.value: the result is of thermodynamic entropy where k is the boltzmann constant

lines.value: we write h(x as h n p 1 ,...,p n ).

lines.value: the shannon entropy satisfies the following properties where k is a positive constant representing the desired unit of measurement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the shannon entropy is restricted to finite sets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it seems that the formula where f denotes a probability density function on the real line is analogous to the shannon entropy and could thus be viewed as an extension of the shannon entropy to the domain of real numbers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: formula * is usually referred to as the continuous entropy or differential entropy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although the analogy between both functions is suggestive the following question must be set is the boltzmann entropy a valid extension of the shannon entropy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to answer this question we must establish a connection between the two functions we wish to obtain a generally finite measure as the bin size goes to zero
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the discrete case the bin size is the implicit width of each of the n finite or infinite bins whose probabilities are denoted by p n
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as we generalize to the continuous domain we must make this width explicit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to do this start with a continuous function f discretized as shown in the figure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as the figure indicates by the mean value theorem there exists a value x i in each bin such that as which is as said before referred to as the differential entropy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this means that the differential entropy is not a limit of the shannon entropy for n → ∞ it turns out as a result that unlike the shannon entropy the differential entropy is not in general a good measure of uncertainty or information
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the differential entropy can be negative also it is not invariant under continuous co ordinate transformations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more useful for the continuous case is the relative entropy of a distribution defined as the kullback leibler divergence from the distribution to a reference measure m(x the relative entropy carries over directly from discrete to continuous distributions and is invariant under co ordinate reparametrisations

lines.value: a molecule with such a charge difference is called a dipole
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the charge differences cause water molecules to be attracted to each other the relatively positive areas being attracted to the relatively negative areas and to other polar molecules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this attraction is known as hydrogen bonding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this relatively weak relative to the covalent bonds within the water molecule itself attraction results in physical properties such as a relatively high boiling point because a lot of heat energy is necessary to break the hydrogen bonds between molecules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example sulfur is the element below oxygen in the periodic table and its equivalent compound hydrogen sulfide h 2 s does not have hydrogen bonds and though it has twice the molecular weight of water it is a gas at room temperature
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the extra bonding between water molecules also gives liquid water a large specific heat capacity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hydrogen bonding also gives water an unusual behaviour when freezing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: just like most other materials the liquid becomes denser with lowering temperature
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however unlike most other materials when cooled to near freezing point the presence of hydrogen bonds means that the molecules as they rearrange to minimise their energy form a structure that is actually of lower density hence the solid form ice will float in water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in other words water expands as it freezes most other materials shrink on solidification
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: liquid water reaches its highest density at a temperature of 4 °c
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this has an interesting consequence for water life in winter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: water chilled at the surface becomes denser and sinks forming convection currents that cool the whole water body but when the temperature of the lake water reaches 4°c water on the surface as it chills further becomes less dense and stays as a surface layer which eventually forms ice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since downward convection of colder water is blocked by the density change any large body of water frozen in winter will have the bulk of its water still liquid at 4°c beneath the icy surface allowing fish to survive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is one of the principal examples of finely tuned physical properties that support life on earth that is used as an argument for the anthropic principle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another consequence is that ice will melt if sufficient pressure is applied.-->
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the area is 10c so the value of the integral is 30.integrals can be taken over regions other than intervals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in general the integral over a set e of a function f is written &int e f(x)dx
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: here x need not be a real number but for instance a vector in r 3
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fubini's theorem shows that such integrals can be rewritten as an iterated integral
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in other words the integral can be calculated by integrating one coordinate at a time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if a function has an integral it is said to be integrable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the function for which the integral is calculated is called the integrand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: integrals are sometimes called definite integrals to emphasize that they result in a number not another function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is to distinguish them from indefinite integrals which are another name for an antiderivative
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the domain of the function is the real numbers and if the region of integration is an interval then the greatest lower bound of the interval is called the lower limit of integration and the least upper bound is called the upper limit of integration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most basic technique for computing integrals of one real variable is based on the fundamental theorem of calculus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it proceeds like this the difficult step is finding an antiderivative of f it is rarely possible to glance at a function and write down its antiderivative
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more often it is necessary to use one of the many techniques that have been developed to evaluate integrals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most of these techniques rewrite one integral as a different one which is hopefully more tractable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: techniques include computation of volumes of solids of revolution can usually be done with disk integration or shell integration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: specific results which have been worked out by various techniques are collected in the list of integrals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: definite integrals may be approximated using several methods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one popular method called the rectangle method or the trapezoidal rule relies on dividing the function into a series of rectangles and finding the sum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another well known method is simpson's rule
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some integrals cannot be found exactly and others are so complex that finding the exact answer would be extremely time consuming or computationally intensive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: approximation however is a process which relies only on variable substitution multiplication addition and division
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it can be done easily and quickly by modern graphing calculators and computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many real-world applications of calculus rely on integral approximation because of the complexity of formulas and unnecessary nature of an exact answer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many professionals educators and students now use computerized algebra systems to make difficult or simply tedious algebra and calculus problems easier
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the design of such a computer algebra system is nontrivial as systematic methods of antidifferentiation are difficult to formulate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one difficulty is that it is not always possible to find nice formulae for antiderivatives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for instance there is a nontrivial proof that there is no nice function e.g involving sin cos exp polynomials roots and so on whose derivative is exp(-x 2 ).
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as such computerized algebra systems have no hope of being able to find an antiderivative for this particular function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unfortunately functions that have nice antiderivatives are the exception
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if one writes a large random expression involving exponentials and polynomials the odds are almost nil that it will have an antiderivative
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this statement can be made formal but it is difficult to do so one of the difficulties is to decide what set of functions to use as building blocks for antiderivatives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: usually we need a set of antiderivatives closed under say multiplication and composition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this set of antiderivatives should also include polynomials perhaps quotients exponentials logarithms sines and cosines
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the risch norman algorithm is able to compute any integral of such a shape that is if the antiderivative involves polynomials sines cosines etc the risch norman algorithm will be able to compute it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: extended versions of this algorithm are implemented in mathematica and maple computer algebra system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some special integrands occur often enough to warrant special study
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in particular it may be useful to have in the set of antiderivatives the special functions of physics like the legendre functions the hypergeometric function fungsi gamma jeung saterusna extending the risch norman algorithm so that it includes these functions is possible but challenging
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most humans are not able to integrate such general formulae so in a sense computers are more skilled at integrating highly complicated formulae
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on the other hand very complex formulae are unlikely to have closed form antiderivatives so this advantage is dubious
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: not all integrals can be evaluated using a single limit process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an integral which can only be evaluated by considering it as the limit of integrals on successively larger and larger integrals is called an improper integral
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: improper integrals usually turn up when the range of the function is infinite or in the case of the riemann integral when the domain is infinite
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one common example of an improper integral is the cauchy principal value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most important integrals are the riemann integral and the lebesgue integral
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the riemann integral was created by bernhard riemann and was the first rigorous definition of the integral
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the lebesgue integral was created by henri lebesgue to integrate a wider class of functions and to prove very strong theorems about interchanging limits and integrals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although the riemann and lebesgue integrals are the most important ones a number of others exist including but not limited to
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the tetrameric form of normal adult hemoglobin the binding of oxygen is a cooperative process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the binding affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen is increased by the oxygen saturation of the molecule
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a consequence the oxygen binding curve of hemoglobin is sigmoidal or s shaped as opposed to the normal hyperbolic curve associated with noncooperative binding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this positive cooperative binding is achieved through steric conformational changes of the hemoglobin protein complex when one subunit protein in hemoglobin becomes oxygenated it induces a conformational or structural change in the whole complex causing the other subunits to gain an increased affinity for oxygen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hemoglobin's oxygen binding capacity is decreased in the presence of carbon monoxide because both gases compete for the same binding sites on hemoglobin carbon monoxide binding preferentially to oxygen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: carbon dioxide occupies a different binding site on the hemoglobin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: through the enzyme carbonic anhydrase carbon dioxide reacts with water to give carbonic acid which decomposes into bicarbonate and protons :co 2 + h 2 o h 2 co 3 hco 3 + h + hence blood with high carbon dioxide levels is also lower in ph more acidic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hemoglobin can bind protons and carbon dioxide which causes a conformational change in the protein and facilitates the release of oxygen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: protons bind at various places along the protein and carbon dioxide binds at the alpha amino group forming carbamate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: conversely when the carbon dioxide levels in the blood decrease i.e around the lungs carbon dioxide is released increasing the oxygen affinity of the protein
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this control of hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen by the binding and release of carbon dioxide is known as the bohr effect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the binding of oxygen is affected by molecules such as carbon monoxide co for example from tobacco smoking cars and furnaces
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: co competes with oxygen at the heme binding site
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hemoglobin binding affinity for co is 200 times greater than its affinity for oxygen meaning that small amounts of co dramatically reduces hemoglobin's ability to transport oxygen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when hemoglobin combines with co it forms a very bright red compound called carboxyhemoglobin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when inspired air contains co levels as low as 0.02% headache and nausea occur if the co concentration is increased to 0.1% unconsciousness will follow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in heavy smokers up to 20% of the oxygen active sites can be blocked by co.hemoglobin also has competitive binding affinity for sulfur monoxide so nitrogen dioxide no 2 ), and hydrogen sulfide h 2 s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the iron atom in the heme group must be in the fe 2+ oxidation state to support oxygen transport
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: oxidation to fe 3+ state converts hemoglobin into hemiglobin or methemoglobin which cannot bind oxygen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nitrogen dioxide and nitrous oxide are capable of converting hemoglobin to methemoglobin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in people acclimated to high altitudes the concentration of 23-bisphosphoglycerate 23-bpg in the blood is increased which allows these individuals to deliver a larger amount of oxygen to tissues under conditions of lower oxygen tension
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this phenomenon where molecule y affects the binding of molecule x to a transport molecule z is called a heterotropic allosteric effect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a variant hemoglobin called fetal hemoglobin hbf a 2 y 2 ), is found in the developing fetus and binds oxygen with greater affinity than adult hemoglobin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this means that the oxygen binding curve for fetal hemoglobin is left shifted i.e a higher percentage of hemoglobin has oxygen bound to it at lower oxygen tension in comparison to that of adult hemoglobin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a result fetal blood in the placenta is able to take oxygen from maternal blood.-->

lines.value: to a small extent hemoglobin a slowly combines with glucose at a certain location in the molecule
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the resulting molecule is often referred to as hb a 1c
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as the concentration of glucose in the blood increases the percentage of hb a that turns into hb a 1c increases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in diabetics whose glucose usually runs high the percent hb a 1c also runs high
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because of the slow rate of hb a combination with glucose the hb a 1c percentage is representative of glucose level in the blood averaged over a longer time the half life of red blood cells which is typically 50-55 days
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hemoglobin levels are amongst the most commonly performed blood tests usually as part of a full blood count or complete blood count
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: results are reported in g/l g dl or mol/l
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for conversion 1 g dl is 0.621 mmol/l
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the hemoglobin level falls below a set point this is called anemia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: anemias are classified by the size of the red blood cells which are the cells which contain hemoglobin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they can be classified as microcytic small sized red blood cells normocytic normal sized red blood cells and macrocytic large sized red blood cells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: glucose levels in blood can vary widely each hour so one or only a few samples from a patient analyzed for glucose may not be representative of glucose control in the long run
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for this reason a blood sample may be analyzed for hb a 1c level which is more representative of glucose control averaged over a longer time period determined by the half life of the individual's red blood cells which is typically 50-55 days
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: people whose hb a 1c runs 6.0% or less show good longer term glucose control
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hb a 1c values which are more than 7.0% are elevated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this test is especially useful for diabetics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this hb a 1c level is only useful in individuals who have red blood cells rbcs with normal survivals i.e normal half life

lines.value: in individuals with abnormal rbcs whether due to abnormal hemoglobin molecules such as hemoglobin s in sickle cell anemia or rbc membrane defects or other problems the rbc half life is frequently shortened

lines.value: in these individuals an alternative test called fructosamine level can be used

lines.value: corresponding to any given name there are one or more hypocoristics affectionate nicknames
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are formed by adding the suffix chan ちゃん to a stem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are two types of stem
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one consists of the full given name
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: examples of this type are taroochan from taroo kimikochan from kimiko and yasunarichan from yasunari
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the other type of stem is a modified stem derived from the full given name
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: examples of such names are tarochan from taroo kiichan from kimiko and yaachan from yasunari
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hypochoristics with modified stems are more intimate than those based on the full given name
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hypochoristics with modified stems are derived by adding chan to a stem consisting of an integral number usually one but occasionally two of feet where a foot consists of two moras
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a mora 音節 is the unit of which a light syllable contains one and a heavy syllable two
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the stems that may be derived from taroo are taro/ consisting of two light syllables and taa/ consisting of a single syllable with a long vowel resulting in tarochan and taachan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the stems that may be derived from hanako are hana/ with two light syllables han/ with one syllable closed by a consonant and haa/ with one syllable with a long vowel resulting in hanachan hanchan and haachan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the segmental content is usually a left substring of that of the given name
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however in some cases it is obtained by other means including the use of another reading of the chinese characters used to write the name
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example a girl named keiko may be called meguchan because the character used to write the kei/ of keiko 恵 can also be read megu/
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in general you may use a hypochoristic only if you have known the person since he or she was a child
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus they may be used for children or for adults whom one has known since they were children
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many ethnic minorities mostly korean and chinese living in japan adopt japanese names to ease communication and more importantly to avoid discrimination
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a few of them still keep their native names
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one ethnic minority who keeps his original name is chang woo han a founder and chairman of maruhan corp a large chain of pachinko parlors in japan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: japanese citizenship requires adopting a japanese name
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in recent decades the government has allowed individuals to simply adopt katakana versions of their native names when applying for citizenship martti turunen who became tsurunen marutei ツルネン マルテイ is a famous example
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: others transliterate their names into phonetically similar kanji compounds such as david aldwinckle who became arudou debito 有道出人
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: still others have abandoned their native names entirely in favor of traditional japanese names such as lafcadio hearn who used the name koizumi yakumo 小泉 八雲
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the time to gain japanese citizenship it was necessary to be adopted by a japanese family in hearn's case it was his wife's family and take their name
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ethnic chinese and koreans in japan sometimes have to change the characters in their names to apply for citizenship because of the restrictions on which kanji can be used
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: individuals born overseas with western given names and japanese surnames are usually given a katakana name in western order when referred to in japanese
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eric shinseki for instance is referred to as エリック シンセキ erikku shinseki
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is a restriction as of 2001 on the use of the v character in a name unless at least one of the parent is of foreign origin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the closest corresponding katakana is ヴ which can be romanized as v or b this affects issuing of japanese passport or other documentations where a romaji representation of the name is given the letter v is replaced with b this affects names such as kevin ケヴィン which would be written as kebin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in plumbing a higher proportion of lead was used

lines.value: this had the advantage of making the alloy solidify more slowly so that it could be wiped over the joint to ensure watertightness

lines.value: although lead water pipes were displaced by copper when it was realized that the lead was poisonous lead solder was still used until the 1980s because it was thought that the amount of lead that could leach into water from the solder was negligible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but even tiny amounts of lead have been found to be detrimental to health so the lead in plumbing solder was replaced by copper or antimony with silver often added and the proportion of tin was increased
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hard solder as used for brazing is generally a copper zinc or copper silver alloy and melts at higher temperatures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eutectic solder has the lowest melting point for solders which is 360 °f
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in silversmithing or jewelry making special hard solders are used that will pass assay
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they contain a high proportion of the metal being soldered and lead is not used in these alloys
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these solders also come in a variety of hardnesses known as enamelling hard medium and easy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: enamelling solder has a high melting point close to that of the material itself to prevent the joint desoldering during firing in the enamelling process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the remaining solder types are used in decreasing order of hardness during the process of making an item to prevent a previously soldered seam or joint desoldering while soldering a new joint
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: easy solder is also often used for repair work for the same reason
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: flux or rouge is also used to prevent joints desoldering
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: solder often comes pre mixed with or is used with flux a reducing agent designed to help remove impurities specifically oxidised metals from the points of contact to improve the electrical connection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for convenience solder is often manufactured as a hollow tube and filled with flux
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most cold solder is soft enough to be rolled and packaged as a coil making for a convenient and compact solder flux package
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the two principal types of flux are acid flux used for metal mending and rosin flux used in electronics where the corrosiveness of the vapours that arise when acid flux is heated could damage components
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: due to concerns over atmospheric pollution and hazardous waste disposal the electronics industry has been gradually shifting from rosin flux to water soluble flux which can be removed with deionised water and detergent instead of hydrocarbon solvents
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since solder can occasionally splash due to the superheated flux inside or from contact with water in the cleaning sponge it is recommended that one always wear safety goggles when soldering
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though small solder splashes on skin are painful they usually do no lasting harm
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for large scale work further protective clothing may be needed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to the european union waste electrical and electronic equipment weee and restriction of hazardous substances directive rohs lead has to be eliminated from electronic systems by july 1 2006 leading to much interest in lead free solders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these contain tin copper silver and sometimes bismuth indium zinc and other metals in varying amounts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the lead free replacements for conventional sn60/pb40 solder have higher melting points requiring reengineering of most components and materials used in electronic assemblies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lead free solder joints may produce mechanically weaker joints depending on service and manufacture conditions which may lead to a decrease in reliability using such solders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tin whiskers are another problem with many lead free solders where slender crystals of tin slowly grow out of the solder joint
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these whiskers can bridge a short circuit years after a device's manufacture

lines.value: in national security the term critical infrastructure is also extremely broad although it should be less inclusive as not all infrastructure should be considered critical and includes support e.g for banking and other such processes of questionable merit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one issue is the necessity of means of protection and of akuntansi in increasing ajen hirup
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: advocates of a broad definition usually argue that without these critical systems the rest of the infrastructure is looted burned or not safe to use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another issue is whether means of persuasion kawas tehnologi komputer or radio or televisi can qualify as infrastructure in any sense as it is more belief sustaining than life sustaining
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the arguments parallel those for means of protection with conservatives generally asserting that belief in a common view of reality especially in emergency response is critical to survival
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term is used most often in an urban planning context to denote the facilities that support specific land uses and built environment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this article focuses on those to avoid the more political issues above
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically infrastructure in this context denotes two general groups of support systems transportation modalities roads rail etc and utilities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these typically compose both public and private systems and some ambiguously held in common
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: infrastructure may also refer to necessary municipal services whether provided by the government or by private companies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if provided by nature e.g the flow of a river they are called nature's services and are distincted at least in economics as the product of natural capital
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this may be augmented or directed by infrastructural capital e.g a dam or canal or irrigation ditch
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in general what is called infrastructure tends to be very embedded in the natural landscape and cannot be moved from place to place
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even municipal services rely necessarily on fixed locations e.g fire stations in central positions in a city transmission towers on tall buildings etc infrastructure in the civic sense includes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: not unusually such a hypothesis states that the parameters or mathematical characteristics of two or more populasi are identical
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example if we want to compare the test scores of two random samples of men and women the null hypothesis would be that the mean score in the male population from which the first sample was drawn was the same as the mean score in the female population from which the second sample was drawn formulation of the null hypothesis is a vital step in statistical significance testing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: having formulated such a hypothesis we can then proceed to establish the probability of observing the data we have actually obtained or data more different from the prediction of the null hypothesis if the null hypothesis is true
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that probability is what is commonly called the significance level of the results
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in formulating a particular null hypothesis we are always also formulating an alternative hypothesis which we will accept if the observed data values are sufficiently improbable under the null hypothesis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the precise formulation of the null hypothesis has implications for the alternative
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example if the null hypothesis is that sample a is drawn from a population with the same mean as sample b the alternative hypothesis is that they come from populations with different means and we shall proceed to a two tailed test of significance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but if the null hypothesis is that sample a is drawn from a population whose mean is no lower than the mean of the population from which sample b is drawn the alternative hypothesis is that sample a comes from a population with a larger mean than the population from which sample b is drawn and we will proceed to a one tailed test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a null hypothesis is only useful if it is possible to calculate the probability of observing a data set with particular parameters from it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in general it is much harder to be precise about how probable the data would be if the alternative hypothesis is true
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if experimental observations contradict the prediction of the null hypothesis it means that either the null hypothesis is false or we have observed an event with very low probability
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this gives us high confidence in the falsehood of the null hypothesis which can be improved by increasing the number of trials
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however accepting the alternative hypothesis only commits us to a difference in observed parameters it does not prove that the theory or principles that predicted such a difference is true since it is always possible that the difference could be due to additional factors not recognised by the theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example rejection of a null hypothesis that say rates of symptom relief in a sample of patients who received a placebo and a sample who received a medicinal drug will be equal allows us to make a non null statement that the rates differed it does not prove that the drug relieved the symptoms though it gives us more confidence in that hypothesis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the formulation testing and rejection of null hypotheses is methodologically consistent with the falsificationist model of scientific discovery formulated by karl popper and widely believed to apply to most kinds of empirical research
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however concerns regarding the high power of statistical tests to detect differences in large samples have led to suggestions for redefining the null hypothesis for example as a hypothesis that an effect falls within a range considered negligible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 2002 a group of psychologists launched a new journal dedicated to experimental studies in psychology which support the null hypothesis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the journal of articles in support of the null hypothesis jasnh was founded to address a scientific publishing bias against such articles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to the editors :"other journals and reviewers have exhibited a bias against articles that did not reject the null hypothesis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: we plan to change that by offering an outlet for experiments that do not reach the traditional significance levels p < 0.05
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus reducing the file drawer problem and reducing the bias in psychological literature
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: without such a resource researchers could be wasting their time examining empirical questions that have already been examined
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: we collect these articles and provide them to the scientific community free of cost for example if you want to see if there is greater divorce avoidance from thomas theory than from edgar theory so your null hypothesis would be thomas theory is no more effective than edgar theory if the probability of the observed results is under the null hypothesis is sufficiently low you can accept the alternative hypothesis that thomas theory is indeed more effective

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: diagram ieu ngindikasikeun arah aliran tipikal dina potongan lintang tina sistim aquifer confined unconfined basajan dua aquifer kalayan hiji aquitard di antarana dilingkung ku bedrock aquiclude nu mana huhubungan jeung aliran tipical dina daerah lembaba ).
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: water table jeung zona henteu jenuh oge diilustrasikeun
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: groundwater can be found at nearly every point in the earth's shallow subsurface to some degree although aquifers do not necessarily contain fresh water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the earth's crust can be divided into two regions the saturated zone e.g aquifers aquitards etc where all available spaces are filled with water and the unsaturated zone also called the vadose zone where there are still pockets of air that can be replaced by water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: saturated means the pressure head of the water is greater than atmospheric pressure it has a gauge pressure > 0
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the definition of the water table is surface where the pressure head is equal to atmospheric pressure where gauge pressure = 0
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unsaturated conditions occur above the water table where the pressure head is negative absolute pressure can never be negative but gauge pressure can and the water which incompletely fills the pores of the aquifer material is under suction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the water content in the unsaturated zone is held in place by surface adhesive forces and it rises above the water table the zero gauge pressure isobar by capillary action to saturate a small zone above the phreatic surface the capillary fringe at less than atmospheric pressure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is termed tension saturation and is not the same as saturation on a water content basis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: water content in a capillary fringe decreases with increasing distance from the phreatic surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the capillary head depends on soil pore size
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in sandy soils with larger pores the head will be less than in clayey soils with very small pores
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the normal capillary rise in a clayey soil is less than six feet but can range between 5 and 100 feet
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the capillary rise of water in a small diameter tube is this same physical process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the water table is the level to which water will rise in a large diameter pipe e.g a well which goes down into the aquifer and is open to the atmosphere
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: *for more detail on the saturation of an aquifer see the water content and soil moisture articles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aquifers are typically saturated regions of the subsurface which produce an economically feasible quantity of water to a well or spring e.g sand and gravel or fractured bedrock often make good aquifer materials
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aquitards sometimes if completely impermeable called an aquiclude or aquifuge are saturated regions which due to lower hydraulic conductivity do not yield a sustainable amount of water in an economic fashion e.g clay silt or fresh bedrock often form aquitards
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: economically feasible is a relative term for example an aquifer that is quite adequate for local domestic use as in a rural area might be considered an inadequate aquitard for industrial mining or urban water supply
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in non mountainous areas or near rivers in mountainous areas the main aquifers are typically unconsolidated alluvium
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are typically composed of mostly horizontal layers of materials deposited by water processes rivers and streams which in cross section looking at a two dimensional slice of the aquifer appear to be layers of alternating coarse and fine materials
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: coarse materials due to the high energy needed to move them tend to be found nearer the source mountain fronts or rivers while the fine grained material will make it farther from the source to the flatter parts of the basin or overbank areas sometimes called the pressure area
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since there are less fine grained deposits near the source this is a place where aquifers are often unconfined sometimes called the forebay area or in hydraulic communication with the land surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: *for more details on ranges of parameters in aquifers and aquitards see the hydraulic conductivity and storativity articles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are two end members in the spectrum of types of aquifers confined and unconfined with semi confined being in between
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unconfined aquifers are sometimes also called water table or phreatic aquifers because their upper boundary is the water table or phreatic surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically but not always the shallowest aquifer at a given location is unconfined meaning it does not have a confining layer an aquitard or aquiclude between it and the surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unconfined aquifers usually receive recharge water directly from the surface from precipitation or from a body of surface water e.g a river stream or lake which is in hydraulic connection with it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: confined aquifers have the water table above their upper boundary an aquitard or aquiclude and are typically found below unconfined aquifers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a perched aquifer occurs when the porous water bearing segment of rock is located on top of a layer of non porous rock
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the distinction between confined and unconfined is not clear geologically i.e if it is not known if a clear confining layer exists or if the geology is more complex e.g a fractured bedrock aquifer the value of storativity returned from an aquifer test can be used to determine it although aquifer tests in unconfined aquifers should be interpreted differently than confined ones
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: confined aquifers have very low storativity values much less than 0.01 and as little as 10 -5 ), which means that the aquifer is storing water using the mechanisms of aquifer matrix expansion and the compressibility of water which typically are both quite small quantities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unconfined aquifers have storativities typically then called specific yield greater than 0.01 1% of bulk volume they release water from storage by the mechanism of actually draining the pores of the aquifer releasing relatively large amounts of water up to the drainable porosity of the aquifer material or the minimum volumetric water content
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: *for more details on parameters related to the confined vs unconfined distinction see the porosity or storativity articles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a common misconception is that groundwater exists in underground rivers e.g caves where water flows freely underground
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is only sometimes true in eroded limestone areas known as karst topography which make up only a small percentage of earth's area
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more usual is that the pore spaces of rocks in the subsurface are simply saturated with water - like a kitchen sponge - which can be pumped out and used for agricultural industrial or municipal uses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the beach is an example of what most aquifers are like
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if you dig a hole into the sand at the beach you will find very wet or saturated sand at a shallow depth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this hole is a crude well the beach sand is an aquifer and the level to which the water rises in this hole represents the water table
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most land areas on earth have some form of aquifer underlying them sometimes at significant depths
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fresh water aquifers especially those with limited recharge by meteoric water can be over exploited and depending on the local hydrogeology may draw in non potable water or saltwater saltwater intrusion from hydraulically connected aquifers or surface water bodies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this can be a serious problem especially in coastal areas and other areas where aquifer pumping is excessive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aquifers are critically important in human habitation and agriculture
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: deep aquifers in arid areas have long been water sources for irrigation see ogallala below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many villages and even large cities draw their water supply from wells in aquifers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some aquifers are riparian aquifers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are related to rivers fluvial deposits or unconsolidated deposits along river corridors and are usually rapidly replenished by infiltration of surface water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some municipal well fields are specifically designed to take advantage of induced infiltration of surface usually river water leaving them potentially vulnerable to water quality problems in the surface water body chemical spills petroleum spills and bacteriological problems
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aquifers that provide sustainable fresh groundwater to urban areas and for agricultural irrigation are typically close to the ground surface within a couple of hundred meters and have some recharge by fresh water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this recharge is typically from rivers or meteoric water precipitation that percolate into the aquifer through overlying unsaturated materials
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in unconsolidated aquifers groundwater is produced from pore spaces between particles of gravel sand and silt
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the aquifer is confined by low permeability layers the reduced water pressure in the sand and gravel causes slow drainage of water from the adjoining confining layers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if these confining layers are composed of compressible silt or clay the loss of water to the aquifer reduces the water pressure in the confining layer causing it to compress due to the weight of overlying geologic materials
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in severe cases this compression can be observed on the ground surface as subsidence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unfortunately much of the subsidence due to groundwater extraction is permanent elastic rebound is small
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus the subsidence is not only permanent but the compressed aquifer has a permanently reduced capacity to hold water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an example of a significant and sustainable carbonate aquifer is the edwards aquifer in central texas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this carbonate aquifer has historically been providing high quality water for nearly 2 million people and even today is completely full because of tremendous recharge from a number of area streams rivers and lakes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the primary risk to this resource is human development over the recharge areas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of the largest aquifers in the world is the guarani aquifer with 1.2 million km² of area from central brazil to northern argentina
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aquifer depletion is a global problem and is especially critical in northern africa see the great manmade river project of libya for an example
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however new methods of groundwater management such as artificial recharge and injection of surface waters during seasonal wet periods has extended the life of many freshwater aquifers especially in the united states
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ogallala aquifer of the central united states is one of the world's great aquifers but in places it is being rapidly depleted for growing municipal use and continuing agricultural use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this huge aquifer which underlies portions of eight states contain primarily fossil water from the time of the last glaciation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: annual recharge in the more arid portions of the aquifer is estimated to total only about ten percent of annual withdrawals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the mahomet aquifer supplies water to some 800000 people in central illinois and contains approximately four trillion us gallons 15 km³ of water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the mahomet aquifer consortium was formed in 1998 to study the aquifer with hopes of ensuring the water supply and reducing potential user conflicts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the great artesian basin is one of the largest groundwater aquifers in the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it plays a large part in water supplies for remote parts of south australia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina elektronik phase locked loop pll nyaeta hiji sistim kadali umpan balik closed loop anu ngajaga sinyal nu dibangkitkeun sangkan aya hubungan fase nu tetep dibandingkeun jeung sinyal referensina
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tehnik ieu loba digunakeun dina radio telekomunikasi komputer jeung aplikasi elektronik sejenna anu miharep distabilkeunnana sinyal nu dibangkitkeun atawa pikeun ngadeteksi sinyal dina kaayaan pinuh ku noise
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ku sabab hiji integrated circuit bisa nyekel blok wangunan phase locked loop sacara lengkap tehnik ieu loba digunakeun dina parangkat elektronik moderen nu miboga frekuensi ti saper sikleus per detik nepi ka sababaraha gigahertz
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: earliest research towards what became known as the phase locked loop goes back to 1932 when british researchers developed an alternative to edwin armstrong's superheterodyne receiver the homodyne
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this so called homodyne or synchrodyne system a local oscillator was tuned to the desired input frequency and multiplied with the input signal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the resulting output signal included the original audio modulation information
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the intent was to develop an alternative receiver circuit that required fewer tuned circuits than the superheterodyne receiver
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the local oscillator would rapidly drift in frequency an automatic correction signal was applied to the oscillator maintaining it in the same phase and frequency as the desired signal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the technique was described in 1932 in a paper by h.de bellescise in the french journal onde electrique
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when signetics introduced a line of monolithic integrated circuits that were complete phase locked loop systems on a chip applications for the technique multiplied
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cd4046 cmos micropower phase locked loop became a popular integrated circuit including two different phase detectors built in
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nyetel benang string dina piano bia dibandingkeun jeung operasi hiji phase locked loop
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ngagunakeun garpu tala atawa pipah nada pikeun nyadiakeun frekuensi referensi tensi string disetel ka luhur atawa ka handap antukna frekuensi irama henteu kadenge
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tepatna ieu mangrupa hiji conto loop anu kakonci frekuensina sabab fase referensi jeung string nu disetel henteu penting kana setelan piano
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: phase locked loop ngarespon boh ka frekuensi oge kana fase tina sinyal asupan nu saterusna naekkeun atawa nurunkeun frekuensi osilator nu dikadalikeun sacara otomatis nepikeun ka saluyu jeung referensi boh frekuensi atawa fasena
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pll ilaharna diwangun tina detektor fase low pass filter sarta voltage controlled oscillator vco nu ditempatkeun dina konfigurasi umpan balik negatip
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mungkin oge ngagunakeun pangbagi dina jalur umpan balik atawa dina jalur referensi atawa dina duanana pikeun ngahasilkeun clock kaluaran minangka pangali rasional tina referensina
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ku jalan ngaganti pangitung counter sederhana nu dibagi n divide-by-n dina jalur umpan balikna ngagunakeun programmable pulse swallowing counter dimungkinkeun pikeun ngahasilkeun pangalian pecahan tina frekuensi referensi di saluareun pll
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the oscillator generates a periodic output signal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: assume that initially the oscillator is at nearly the same frequency as the reference signal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then if the phase from the oscillator falls behind that of the reference the phase detector causes the charge pump to change the control voltage so that the oscillator speeds up
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: likewise if the phase creeps ahead of the reference the phase detector causes the charge pump to change the control voltage to slow down the oscillator
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the low pass filter smooths out the abrupt control inputs from the charge pump
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since initially the oscillator may be far from the reference frequency practical phase detectors may also respond to frequency differences so as to increase the lock in range of allowable inputs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: depending on the application either the output of the controlled oscillator or the control signal to the oscillator provides the useful output of the pll system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most plls also include a divider between the vco and the feedback input to the phase detector to produce a frequency synthesiser
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a programmable divider is particularly useful in radio transmitter applications since a large number of transmit frequencies can be produced from a single stable accurate but expensive quartz crystal controlled reference oscillator
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some plls also include a divider between the reference clock and the reference input to the phase detector
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if this divider divides by
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it might seem simpler to just feed the pll a lower frequency but in some cases the reference frequency may be constrained by other issues and then the reference divider is useful
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: phase locked loops are widely used for synchronization purposes in space communications for coherent carrier tracking and threshold extension bit synchronization and symbol synchronization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: phase locked loops can also be used to demodulate frequency modulated signals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in radio transmitters a pll is used to synthesize new frequencies which are a multiple of a reference frequency with the same stability as the reference frequency
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aplikasi sejenna kaasup diantarana deskewing if a clock is sent in parallel with data that clock can be used to sample the data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because the clock must be received and amplified before it can drive the flip flops which sample the data there will be a finite and process- temperature- and voltage dependent delay between the detected clock edge and the received data window
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this delay limits the frequency at which data can be sent
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one way of eliminating this delay is to include a deskew pll on the receive side so that the clock at each data flip flop is phase matched to the received clock
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: clock generation most electronic systems include processors of various sorts that operate at hundreds of megahertz
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically the clocks supplied to these processors come from clock generator plls which multiply a lower frequency reference clock usually 50 or 100 mhz up to the operating frequency of the processor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the multiplication factor can be quite large in cases where the operating frequency is multiple gigahertz and the reference crystal is just tens or hundreds of megahertz
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: spread spectrum all electronic systems emit some unwanted radio frequency energy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: various regulatory agencies such as the fcc in the united states put limits on this emitted energy and any interference caused by it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the emitted noise generally appears at sharp spectral peaks usually at the operating frequency of the device and a few harmonics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a system designer can use a spread spectrum pll to reduce interference with high q receivers by spreading the energy over a larger portion of the spectrum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example by changing the operating frequency up and down by a small amount about 1% a device running at hundreds of megahertz can spread its interference evenly over a few megahertz of spectrum which drastically reduces the amount of noise seen by fm receivers which have a bandwidth of tens of kilohertz
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an important part of a phase locked loop is the phase detector
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this compares the phase of the local oscillator to that of the reference signal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are several types of phase detectors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the simplest is an exclusive or gate which maintains a 90° phase difference but cannot lock the signal unless it is already near frequency
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a more complex phase detector uses a simple state machine to determine which of the two signals has a zero crossing earlier or more often
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this brings the pll into lock even when it is off frequency
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this type is known as a phase frequency detector
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a four quadrant multiplier also known as a mixer can be used as a phase detector
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by multiplying the oscillator and the reference signals this generates an output consisting of a low frequency signal whose amplitude is related to the phase difference or phase error between the oscillator and the reference and a second unwanted signal at twice the oscillator frequency that is eliminated by a low pass filter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a pll with a bang bang charge pump phase detector supplies current pulses with fixed total charge either positive or negative to the capacitor acting as an integrator
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a phase detector for a bang bang charge pump must always have a dead band where the phases of the reference and feedback clocks are close enough that the detector fires either both or neither of the charge pumps for no total effect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bang bang control systems are simple but are associated with significant minimum peak to peak jitter because once in lock the phase offset hunts between the two extrema values of the dead band
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a proportional phase detector directs the charge pump to supply charge amounts in proportion to the phase error detected
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although some proportional phase detectors have dead bands some do not
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: specifically some designs arrange to produce both up and down control pulses when the phase offset is zero
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these pulses are small nominally the same duration and cause the charge pump to produce equal charge positive and negative current pulses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a proportional phase detector does not necessarily hunt while in lock and so plls with this kind of control system typically have lower minimum peak to peak jitter that is determined by other limiting factors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: inductive oscillators lc oscillators are built of an lc tank circuit which oscillates by charging and discharging a capacitor through an inductor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these oscillators are typically used when a tunable precision frequency source is necessary such as with radio transmitters and receivers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most lc oscillators use off chip inductors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on chip inductors suffer large resistive losses so that the q of the resulting tank circuit is generally less than 10
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as processes have made larger numbers of metal layers available on chip inductors have become more useful
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a voltage controlled capacitor is one method of making an lc oscillator vary its frequency in response to a control voltage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: any reversebiased semiconductor diode displays a measure of voltage dependent capacitance and can be used to change the frequency of an oscillator by varying a control voltage applied to the diodes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: special purpose variable capacitance varactor diodes are available with well characterized wide ranging values of capacitance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such devices are very convenient in the manufacture of voltage controlled oscillators a voltage controlled inductor would be in principle as useful but such devices are unsatisfactory at the frequencies usually desired
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: crystal oscillators are piezoelectric quartz crystals that mechanically vibrate between two slightly different shapes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: crystals have very high q and can only be tuned within a very small range of frequencies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: crystal oscillators are typically used as the frequency reference for other plls and can be found in nearly every consumer electronic device
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because the crystal is an off chip component it adds some cost and complexity to the system design but the crystal itself is generally quite inexpensive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :surface-acoustic-wave devices saws are a kind of crystal oscillator but achieve much higher frequencies by establishing standing waves on the surface of the quartz crystal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are more expensive than crystal oscillators and are used in more specialized applications which require a direct and very accurate high frequency reference for example in cellular telephones
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for a pll built into a microprocessor chip ring oscillators can be used as voltage controlled oscillators vcos
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are built of a ring of active delay stages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: generally the ring has an odd number of inverting stages so that there is no single stable state for the internal ring voltages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: instead a single transition propagates endlessly around the ring
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the frequency is controlled by varying either the supply voltage or the capacitive loading on each stage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: vcos generally have the lowest q of the used oscillators and so suffer more jitter than the other types
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the jitter can be made low enough for many applications such as driving an asic in which case vcos enjoy the advantages of having no off chip components expensive or on chip inductors low yields on generic cmos processes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these oscillators also have larger tuning ranges than the other kinds which improves yield and is sometimes a feature of the end product for instance the dot clock on a graphics card which drives a wide range of monitors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically the reference clock enters the chip and drives a phase locked loop pll which then drives the system's clock distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the clock distribution is usually balanced so that the clock arrives at every endpoint simultaneously
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of those endpoints is the pll's feedback input
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the function of the pll is to compare the distributed clock to the incoming reference clock and vary the phase and frequency of its output until the reference and feedback clocks are phase and frequency matched
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from a control theory perspective the pll is a special case of the kalman filter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: plls are ubiquitous they tune clocks in systems several feet across as well as clocks in small portions of individual chips
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometimes the reference clock may not actually be a pure clock at all but rather a data stream with enough transitions that the pll is able to recover a regular clock from that stream
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometimes the reference clock is the same frequency as the clock driven through the clock distribution other times the distributed clock may be some rational multiple of the reference
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one desirable property of all plls is that the reference and feedback clock edges be brought into very close alignment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the average difference in time between the phases of the two signals when the pll has achieved lock is called the static phase offset
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the variance between these phases is called tracking jitter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ideally the static phase offset should be zero and the tracking jitter should be as low as possible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: phase noise is another type of jitter observed in plls and is mostly caused by the amplifier elements used in the circuit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some technologies are known to perform better than others in this regard
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the best digital plls are constructed with emitter coupled logic ecl elements at the expense of high power consumption
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to keep phase noise low in pll circuits it is best to avoid saturating logic families such as transistor transistor logic ttl or cmos
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another desirable property of all plls is that the phase and frequency of the generated clock be unaffected by rapid changes in the voltages of the power and ground supply lines as well as the voltage of the substrate on which the pll circuits are fabricated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is called supply and substrate noise rejection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the equations governing a phase locked loop with an analogue multiplier as the phase detector may be derived as follows
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: let the input to the phase detector be the loop filter receives this signal as input and produces an output this can be rewritten into sum and difference components using trigonometric identities :
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the phase locked loop is said to be locked if this is the case
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some parts of this article are derived from public domain parts of federal standard 1037c in support of mil std 188
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: phase locked loops can also be analyzed as control systems by applying the laplace transform
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the loop response can be written as the loop response becomes the loop natural frequency is a measure of the response time of the loop and the damping factor is a measure of the overshoot and ringing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ideally the natural frequency should be high and the damping factor should be near 0.707 critical damping
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with a single pole filter it is not possible to control the loop frequency and damping factor independently
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for the case of critical damping the loop filter components can be calculated independently for a given natural frequency and damping factor
lines.name: Sundanese
